2394  APIs for retrieving Serialized Dictionary Information by tablespace id
2395  */
2396 
2397  sdi_create_t sdi_create;
2398  sdi_drop_t sdi_drop;
2399  sdi_get_keys_t sdi_get_keys;
2400  sdi_get_t sdi_get;
2401  sdi_set_t sdi_set;
2402  sdi_delete_t sdi_delete;
2403 
2404  /**
2405  Null-ended array of file extentions that exist for the storage engine.
2406  Used by frm_error() and the default handler::rename_table and delete_table
2407  methods in handler.cc.
2408 
2409  For engines that have two file name extentions (separate meta/index file
2410  and data file), the order of elements is relevant. First element of engine
2411  file name extentions array should be meta/index file extention. Second
2412  element - data file extention. This order is assumed by
2413  prepare_for_repair() when REPAIR TABLE ... USE_FRM is issued.
2414 
2415  For engines that don't have files, file_extensions is NULL.
2416 
2417  Currently, the following alternatives are used:
2418  - file_extensions == NULL;
2419  - file_extensions[0] != NULL, file_extensions[1] == NULL;
2420  - file_extensions[0] != NULL, file_extensions[1] != NULL,
2421  file_extensions[2] == NULL;
2422  */
2423  const char **file_extensions;
2424 
2425  is_dict_readonly_t is_dict_readonly;
2426  rm_tmp_tables_t rm_tmp_tables;
2427  get_cost_constants_t get_cost_constants;
2428  replace_native_transaction_in_thd_t replace_native_transaction_in_thd;
2429  notify_exclusive_mdl_t notify_exclusive_mdl;
2430  notify_alter_table_t notify_alter_table;
2431  rotate_encryption_master_key_t rotate_encryption_master_key;
2432  redo_log_set_state_t redo_log_set_state;
2433 
2434  get_table_statistics_t get_table_statistics;
2435  get_index_column_cardinality_t get_index_column_cardinality;
2436  get_tablespace_statistics_t get_tablespace_statistics;
2437 
2438  post_ddl_t post_ddl;
2439  post_recover_t post_recover;
2440 
2441  /** Clone data transfer interfaces */
2442  Clone_interface_t clone_interface;
2443 
2444  /** Flag for Engine License. */
2445  uint32 license;
2446  /** Location for engines to keep personal structures. */
2447  void *data;
2448 
2449  /*
2450  Log_resource functions that must be supported by storage engines
2451  with relevant log information to be collected.
2452  */
2453  lock_hton_log_t lock_hton_log;
2454  unlock_hton_log_t unlock_hton_log;
2455  collect_hton_log_info_t collect_hton_log_info;
2456 
2457  /** Flags describing details of foreign key support by storage engine. */
2458  uint32 foreign_keys_flags;
2459 
2460  check_fk_column_compat_t check_fk_column_compat;
2461 
2462  /**
2463  Suffix for auto-generated foreign key names for tables using this storage
2464  engine. If such suffix is specified by SE then its generated foreign key
2465  names follow (table name)(SE-specific FK name suffix)(FK number) pattern.
2466  Length of such suffix should not exceed MAX_FK_NAME_SUFFIX_LENGTH bytes.
2467  If no suffix is specified then FK_NAME_DEFAULT_SUFFIX is used as
2468  default.
2469  */
2470  LEX_CSTRING fk_name_suffix;
2471 
2472  /**
2473  Pointer to a function that prepares a secondary engine for executing a
2474  statement.
2475 
2476  @see prepare_secondary_engine_t for function signature.
2477  */
2478  prepare_secondary_engine_t prepare_secondary_engine;
2479 
2480  /**
2481  Pointer to a function that optimizes the current statement for
2482  execution on the secondary storage engine represented by this
2483  handlerton.
2484 
2485  @see optimize_secondary_engine_t for function signature.
2486  */
2487  optimize_secondary_engine_t optimize_secondary_engine;
2488 
2489  /**
2490  Pointer to a function that estimates the cost of executing a join in a
2491  secondary storage engine.
2492 
2493  @see compare_secondary_engine_cost_t for function signature.
2494  */
2495  compare_secondary_engine_cost_t compare_secondary_engine_cost;
2496 
2497  se_before_commit_t se_before_commit;
2498  se_after_commit_t se_after_commit;
2499  se_before_rollback_t se_before_rollback;
2500 
2501  /** Page tracking interface */
2502  Page_track_t page_track;
2503 };
2504 
2505 /* Possible flags of a handlerton (there can be 32 of them) */
2506 #define HTON_NO_FLAGS 0
2507 #define HTON_CLOSE_CURSORS_AT_COMMIT (1 << 0)
2508 #define HTON_ALTER_NOT_SUPPORTED (1 << 1) // Engine does not support alter
2509 #define HTON_CAN_RECREATE (1 << 2) // Delete all is used fro truncate
2510 #define HTON_HIDDEN (1 << 3) // Engine does not appear in lists
2511 /*
2512  Bit 4 was occupied by BDB-specific HTON_FLUSH_AFTER_RENAME flag and is no
2513  longer used.
2514 */
2515 #define HTON_NOT_USER_SELECTABLE (1 << 5)
2516 #define HTON_TEMPORARY_NOT_SUPPORTED \
2517  (1 << 6) // Having temporary tables not supported
2518 #define HTON_SUPPORT_LOG_TABLES (1 << 7) // Engine supports log tables
2519 #define HTON_NO_PARTITION (1 << 8) // You can not partition these tables
2520 
2521 /*
2522  This flag should be set when deciding that the engine does not allow row based
2523  binary logging (RBL) optimizations.
2524 
2525  Currently, setting this flag, means that table's read/write_set will be left
2526  untouched when logging changes to tables in this engine. In practice this
2527  means that the server will not mess around with table->write_set and/or
2528  table->read_set when using RBL and deciding whether to log full or minimal
2529  rows.
2530 
2531  It's valuable for instance for virtual tables, eg: Performance Schema which
2532  have no meaning for replication.
2533 */
2534 #define HTON_NO_BINLOG_ROW_OPT (1 << 9)
2535 
2536 /**
2537  Engine supports extended keys. The flag allows to
2538  use 'extended key' feature if the engine is able to
2539  do it (has primary key values in the secondary key).
2540  Note that handler flag HA_PRIMARY_KEY_IN_READ_INDEX is
2541  actually partial case of HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS.
2542 */
2543 
2544 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS (1 << 10)
2545 
2546 // Engine support foreign key constraint.
2547 
2548 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_FOREIGN_KEYS (1 << 11)
2549 
2550 /**
2551  Engine supports atomic DDL. That is rollback of transaction for DDL
2552  statement will also rollback all changes in SE, commit of transaction
2553  of DDL statement will make it durable.
2554 */
2555 
2556 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL (1 << 12)
2557 
2558 /* Engine supports packed keys. */
2559 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_PACKED_KEYS (1 << 13)
2560 
2561 /** Engine is a secondary storage engine. */
2562 #define HTON_IS_SECONDARY_ENGINE (1 << 14)
2563 
2564 /** Engine supports secondary storage engines. */
2565 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_SECONDARY_ENGINE (1 << 15)
2566 
2567 /** Engine supports table or tablespace encryption . */
2568 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_TABLE_ENCRYPTION (1 << 16)
2569 
2570 constexpr const decltype(handlerton::flags) HTON_SUPPORTS_ENGINE_ATTRIBUTE{
2571  1 << 17};
2572 
2573 inline bool ddl_is_atomic(const handlerton *hton) {
2574  return (hton->flags & HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL) != 0;
2575 }
2576 
2577 /* Bits for handlerton::foreign_keys_flags bitmap. */
2578 
2579 /**
2580  Engine supports both unique and non-unique parent keys for
2581  foreign keys which contain full foreign key as its prefix.
2582 
2583  Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have
2584  this flag set are assumed to support only parent keys which
2585  are primary/unique and contain exactly the same columns as
2586  the foreign key, possibly, in different order.
2587 */
2588 
2589 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_PREFIX_PARENT_KEYS = (1 << 0);
2590 
2591 /**
2592  Storage engine supports hash keys as supporting keys for foreign
2593  keys. Hash key should contain all foreign key columns and only
2594  them (altough in any order).
2595 
2596  Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have this
2597  flag set are assumed to not allow hash keys as supporting keys.
2598 */
2599 
2600 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_SUPPORTING_HASH_KEYS = (1 << 1);
2601 
2602 /**
2603  Storage engine supports non-hash keys which have common prefix
2604  with the foreign key as supporting keys for it. If there are
2605  several such keys, one which shares biggest prefix with FK is
2606  chosen.
2607 
2608  Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have this
2609  flag set are assumed to require that supporting key contains full
2610  foreign key as its prefix.
2611 */
2612 
2613 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_ANY_PREFIX_SUPPORTING_KEYS = (1 << 2);
2614 
2615 /**
2616  Storage engine does not support using the same key for both parent
2617  and supporting key, but requires the two to be different.
2618 */
2619 
2620 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_NEED_DIFFERENT_PARENT_AND_SUPPORTING_KEYS =
2621  (1 << 3);
2622 
2623 /**
2624  Engine takes into account hidden part of key (coming from primary key)
2625  when determines if it can serve as parent key for a foreign key.
2626 
2627  Implies HTON_FKS_WITH_PREFIX_PARENT_KEYS and is related to
2628  HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS.
2629 */
2630 
2631 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_EXTENDED_PARENT_KEYS = (1 << 4);
2632 
2633 /**
2634  Maximum possible length of SE-specific suffixes for auto-generated
2635  foreign key names.
2636 */
2637 static const size_t MAX_FK_NAME_SUFFIX_LENGTH = 16;
2638 
2639 /**
2640  Suffix for auto-generated foreign key names for tables in SE's which
2641  don't specify own suffix. I.e. for foreign keys on tables in such
2642  SE's generated names follow (table name)FK_NAME_DEFAULT_SUFFIX(FK number)
2643  pattern.
2644 */
2645 static const LEX_CSTRING FK_NAME_DEFAULT_SUFFIX = {STRING_WITH_LEN("_fk_")};
2646 
2647 enum enum_tx_isolation : int {
2648  ISO_READ_UNCOMMITTED,
2649  ISO_READ_COMMITTED,
2650  ISO_REPEATABLE_READ,
2651  ISO_SERIALIZABLE
2652 };
2653 
2654 enum enum_stats_auto_recalc : int {
2655  HA_STATS_AUTO_RECALC_DEFAULT = 0,
2656  HA_STATS_AUTO_RECALC_ON,
2657  HA_STATS_AUTO_RECALC_OFF
2658 };
2659 
2660 /* struct to hold information about the table that should be created */
2661 struct HA_CREATE_INFO {
2662  const CHARSET_INFO *table_charset{nullptr};
2663  const CHARSET_INFO *default_table_charset{nullptr};
2664  bool schema_read_only{false};
2665  LEX_STRING connect_string{nullptr, 0};
2666  const char *password{nullptr};
2667  const char *tablespace{nullptr};
2668  LEX_STRING comment{nullptr, 0};
2669 
2670  /**
2671  Algorithm (and possible options) to be used for InnoDB's transparent
2672  page compression. If this attribute is set then it is hint to the
2673  storage engine to try and compress the data using the specified algorithm
2674  where possible. Note: this value is interpreted by the storage engine only.
2675  and ignored by the Server layer. */
2676 
2677  LEX_STRING compress{nullptr, 0};
2678 
2679  /**
2680  This attibute is used for InnoDB's transparent page encryption.
2681  If this attribute is set then it is hint to the storage engine to encrypt
2682  the data. Note: this value is interpreted by the storage engine only.
2683  and ignored by the Server layer. */
2684 
2685  LEX_STRING encrypt_type{nullptr, 0};
2686 
2687  /**
2688  * Secondary engine of the table.
2689  * Is nullptr if no secondary engine defined.
2690  */
2691  LEX_CSTRING secondary_engine{nullptr, 0};
2692 
2693  const char *data_file_name{nullptr};
2694  const char *index_file_name{nullptr};
2695  const char *alias{nullptr};
2696  ulonglong max_rows{0};
2697  ulonglong min_rows{0};
2698  ulonglong auto_increment_value{0};
2699  ulong table_options{0};
2700  ulong avg_row_length{0};
2701  uint64_t used_fields{0};
2702  ulong key_block_size{0};
2703  uint stats_sample_pages{0}; /* number of pages to sample during
2704  stats estimation, if used, otherwise 0. */
2705  enum_stats_auto_recalc stats_auto_recalc{HA_STATS_AUTO_RECALC_DEFAULT};
2706  SQL_I_List<TABLE_LIST> merge_list;
2707  handlerton *db_type{nullptr};
2708  /**
2709  Row type of the table definition.
2710 
2711  Defaults to ROW_TYPE_DEFAULT for all non-ALTER statements.
2712  For ALTER TABLE defaults to ROW_TYPE_NOT_USED (means "keep the current").
2713 
2714  Can be changed either explicitly by the parser.
2715  If nothing specified inherits the value of the original table (if present).
2716  */
2717  enum row_type row_type = ROW_TYPE_DEFAULT;
2718  uint null_bits{0}; /* NULL bits at start of record */
2719  uint options{0}; /* OR of HA_CREATE_ options */
2720  uint merge_insert_method{0};
2721  ha_storage_media storage_media{HA_SM_DEFAULT}; /* DEFAULT, DISK or MEMORY */
2722 
2723  /*
2724  A flag to indicate if this table should be marked as a hidden table in
2725  the data dictionary. One use case is to mark the temporary tables
2726  created by ALTER to be marked as hidden.
2727  */
2728  bool m_hidden{false};
2729 
2730  /*
2731  A flag to indicate if this table should be created but not committed at
2732  the end of statement.
2733  */
2734  bool m_transactional_ddl{false};
2735 
2736  LEX_CSTRING engine_attribute = NULL_CSTR;
2737  LEX_CSTRING secondary_engine_attribute = NULL_CSTR;
2738 
2739  /**
2740  Fill HA_CREATE_INFO to be used by ALTER as well as upgrade code.
2741  This function separates code from mysql_prepare_alter_table() to be
2742  used by upgrade code as well to reduce code duplication.
2743  For ALTER code path, this lets new create options override the old
2744  ones.
2745 
2746  @param[in] share TABLE_SHARE object
2747  @param[in] used_fields If a given create option is not flagged, old
2748  value be copied from the TABLE_SHARE.
2749  */
2750 
2751  void init_create_options_from_share(const TABLE_SHARE *share,
2752  uint used_fields);
2753 };
2754 
2755 /**
2756  Structure describing changes to an index to be caused by ALTER TABLE.
2757 */
2758 
2759 struct KEY_PAIR {
2760  /**
2761  Pointer to KEY object describing old version of index in
2762  TABLE::key_info array for TABLE instance representing old
2763  version of table.
2764  */
2765  KEY *old_key;
2766  /**
2767  Pointer to KEY object describing new version of index in
2768  Alter_inplace_info::key_info_buffer array.
2769  */
2770  KEY *new_key;
2771 };
2772 
2773 /**
2774  In-place alter handler context.
2775 
2776  This is a superclass intended to be subclassed by individual handlers
2777  in order to store handler unique context between in-place alter API calls.
2778 
2779  The handler is responsible for creating the object. This can be done
2780  as early as during check_if_supported_inplace_alter().
2781 
2782  The SQL layer is responsible for destroying the object.
2783 
2784  @see Alter_inplace_info
2785 */
2786 
2787 class inplace_alter_handler_ctx {
2788  public:
2789  inplace_alter_handler_ctx() {}
2790 
2791  virtual void set_shared_data(
2792  const inplace_alter_handler_ctx *ctx MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {}
2793  virtual ~inplace_alter_handler_ctx() {}
2794 };
2795 
2796 /**
2797  Class describing changes to be done by ALTER TABLE.
2798  Instance of this class is passed to storage engine in order
2799  to determine if this ALTER TABLE can be done using in-place
2800  algorithm. It is also used for executing the ALTER TABLE
2801  using in-place algorithm.
2802 */
2803 
2804 class Alter_inplace_info {
2805  public:
2806  /**
2807  Bits to show in detail what operations the storage engine is
2808  to execute.
2809 
2810  All these operations are supported as in-place operations by the
2811  SQL layer. This means that operations that by their nature must
2812  be performed by copying the table to a temporary table, will not
2813  have their own flags here (e.g. ALTER TABLE FORCE, ALTER TABLE
2814  ENGINE).
2815 
2816  We generally try to specify handler flags only if there are real
2817  changes. But in cases when it is cumbersome to determine if some
2818  attribute has really changed we might choose to set flag
2819  pessimistically, for example, relying on parser output only.
2820  */
2821  typedef ulonglong HA_ALTER_FLAGS;
2822 
2823  // Add non-unique, non-primary index
2824  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_INDEX = 1ULL << 0;
2825 
2826  // Drop non-unique, non-primary index
2827  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_INDEX = 1ULL << 1;
2828 
2829  // Add unique, non-primary index
2830  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_UNIQUE_INDEX = 1ULL << 2;
2831 
2832  // Drop unique, non-primary index
2833  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_UNIQUE_INDEX = 1ULL << 3;
2834 
2835  // Add primary index
2836  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_PK_INDEX = 1ULL << 4;
2837 
2838  // Drop primary index
2839  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_PK_INDEX = 1ULL << 5;
2840 
2841  // Add column
2842 
2843  // Virtual generated column
2844  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_VIRTUAL_COLUMN = 1ULL << 6;
2845  // Stored base (non-generated) column
2846  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_STORED_BASE_COLUMN = 1ULL << 7;
2847  // Stored generated column
2848  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_STORED_GENERATED_COLUMN = 1ULL << 8;
2849  // Add generic column (convience constant).
2850  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_COLUMN =
2851  ADD_VIRTUAL_COLUMN | ADD_STORED_BASE_COLUMN | ADD_STORED_GENERATED_COLUMN;
2852 
2853  // Drop column
2854  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_VIRTUAL_COLUMN = 1ULL << 9;
2855  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_STORED_COLUMN = 1ULL << 10;
2856  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_COLUMN =
2857  DROP_VIRTUAL_COLUMN | DROP_STORED_COLUMN;
2858 
2859  // Rename column
2860  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_NAME = 1ULL << 11;
2861 
2862  // Change column datatype
2863  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_VIRTUAL_COLUMN_TYPE = 1ULL << 12;
2864  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_STORED_COLUMN_TYPE = 1ULL << 13;
2865 
2866  /**
2867  Change column datatype in such way that new type has compatible
2868  packed representation with old type, so it is theoretically
2869  possible to perform change by only updating data dictionary
2870  without changing table rows.
2871  */
2872  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_EQUAL_PACK_LENGTH = 1ULL << 14;
2873 
2874  /// A virtual column has changed its position
2875  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_VIRTUAL_COLUMN_ORDER = 1ULL << 15;
2876 
2877  /// A stored column has changed its position (disregarding virtual columns)
2878  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_STORED_COLUMN_ORDER = 1ULL << 16;
2879 
2880  // Change column from NOT NULL to NULL
2881  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_NULLABLE = 1ULL << 17;
2882 
2883  // Change column from NULL to NOT NULL
2884  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_NOT_NULLABLE = 1ULL << 18;
2885 
2886  // Set or remove default column value
2887  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_DEFAULT = 1ULL << 19;
2888 
2889  // Change column generation expression
2890  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_VIRTUAL_GCOL_EXPR = 1ULL << 20;
2891  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_STORED_GCOL_EXPR = 1ULL << 21;
2892 
2893  // Add foreign key
2894  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_FOREIGN_KEY = 1ULL << 22;
2895 
2896  // Drop foreign key
2897  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_FOREIGN_KEY = 1ULL << 23;
2898 
2899  // table_options changed, see HA_CREATE_INFO::used_fields for details.
2900  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS CHANGE_CREATE_OPTION = 1ULL << 24;
2901 
2902  // Table is renamed
2903  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_RENAME = 1ULL << 25;
2904 
2905  // Change the storage type of column
2906  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_STORAGE_TYPE = 1ULL << 26;
2907 
2908  // Change the column format of column
2909  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_COLUMN_FORMAT = 1ULL << 27;
2910 
2911  // Add partition
2912  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_PARTITION = 1ULL << 28;
2913 
2914  // Drop partition
2915  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_PARTITION = 1ULL << 29;
2916 
2917  // Changing partition options
2918  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_PARTITION = 1ULL << 30;
2919 
2920  // Coalesce partition
2921  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS COALESCE_PARTITION = 1ULL << 31;
2922 
2923  // Reorganize partition ... into
2924  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS REORGANIZE_PARTITION = 1ULL << 32;
2925 
2926  // Reorganize partition
2927  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_TABLE_REORG = 1ULL << 33;
2928 
2929  // Remove partitioning
2930  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_REMOVE_PARTITIONING = 1ULL << 34;
2931 
2932  // Partition operation with ALL keyword
2933  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_ALL_PARTITION = 1ULL << 35;
2934 
2935  /**
2936  Rename index. Note that we set this flag only if there are no other
2937  changes to the index being renamed. Also for simplicity we don't
2938  detect renaming of indexes which is done by dropping index and then
2939  re-creating index with identical definition under different name.
2940  */
2941  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS RENAME_INDEX = 1ULL << 36;
2942 
2943  /**
2944  Recreate the table for ALTER TABLE FORCE, ALTER TABLE ENGINE
2945  and OPTIMIZE TABLE operations.
2946  */
2947  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS RECREATE_TABLE = 1ULL << 37;
2948 
2949  // Add spatial index
2950  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_SPATIAL_INDEX = 1ULL << 38;
2951 
2952  // Alter index comment
2953  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_INDEX_COMMENT = 1ULL << 39;
2954 
2955  // New/changed virtual generated column require validation
2956  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS VALIDATE_VIRTUAL_COLUMN = 1ULL << 40;
2957 
2958  /**
2959  Change index option in a way which is likely not to require index
2960  recreation. For example, change COMMENT or KEY::is_algorithm_explicit
2961  flag (without change of index algorithm itself).
2962  */
2963  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS CHANGE_INDEX_OPTION = 1LL << 41;
2964 
2965  // Rebuild partition
2966  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_REBUILD_PARTITION = 1ULL << 42;
2967 
2968  /**
2969  Change in index length such that it does not require index rebuild.
2970  For example, change in index length due to column expansion like
2971  varchar(X) changed to varchar(X + N).
2972  */
2973  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_INDEX_LENGTH = 1ULL << 43;
2974 
2975  /**
2976  Change to one of columns on which virtual generated column depends,
2977  so its values require re-evaluation.
2978  */
2979  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS VIRTUAL_GCOL_REEVAL = 1ULL << 44;
2980 
2981  /**
2982  Change to one of columns on which stored generated column depends,
2983  so its values require re-evaluation.
2984  */
2985  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS STORED_GCOL_REEVAL = 1ULL << 45;
2986 
2987  // Add check constraint.
2988  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_CHECK_CONSTRAINT = 1ULL << 46;
2989 
2990  // Drop check constraint.
2991  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_CHECK_CONSTRAINT = 1ULL << 47;
2992 
2993  // Suspend check constraint.
2994  static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS SUSPEND_CHECK_CONSTRAINT = 1ULL << 48;
2995 
2996  /**
2997  Create options (like MAX_ROWS) for the new version of table.
2998 
2999  @note The referenced instance of HA_CREATE_INFO object was already
3000  used to create new .FRM file for table being altered. So it
3001  has been processed by mysql_prepare_create_table() already.
3002  For example, this means that it has HA_OPTION_PACK_RECORD
3003  flag in HA_CREATE_INFO::table_options member correctly set.
3004  */
3005  HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info;
3006 
3007  /**
3008  Alter options, fields and keys for the new version of table.
3009 
3010  @note The referenced instance of Alter_info object was already
3011  used to create new .FRM file for table being altered. So it
3012  has been processed by mysql_prepare_create_table() already.
3013  In particular, this means that in Create_field objects for
3014  fields which were present in some form in the old version
3015  of table, Create_field::field member points to corresponding
3016  Field instance for old version of table.
3017  */
3018  Alter_info *alter_info;
3019 
3020  /**
3021  Indicates whether operation should fail if table is non-empty.
3022  Storage engines should not suggest/allow execution of such operations
3023  using INSTANT algorithm since check whether table is empty done from
3024  SQL-layer is not "instant". Also SEs might choose different algorithm for
3025  ALTER TABLE execution knowing that it will be allowed to proceed only if
3026  table is empty.
3027 
3028  Unlike for Alter_table_ctx::error_if_not_empty, we use bool for this flag
3029  and not bitmap, since SEs are really interested in the fact that ALTER
3030  will fail if table is not empty and not in exact reason behind this fact,
3031  and because we want to avoid extra dependency between Alter_table_ctx and
3032  Alter_inplace_info.
3033  */
3034  bool error_if_not_empty;
3035 
3036  /**
3037  Array of KEYs for new version of table - including KEYs to be added.
3038 
3039  @note Currently this array is produced as result of
3040  mysql_prepare_create_table() call.
3041  This means that it follows different convention for
3042  KEY_PART_INFO::fieldnr values than objects in TABLE::key_info
3043  array.
3044 
3045  @todo This is mainly due to the fact that we need to keep compatibility
3046  with removed handler::add_index() call. We plan to switch to
3047  TABLE::key_info numbering later.
3048 
3049  KEYs are sorted - see sort_keys().
3050  */
3051  KEY *key_info_buffer;
3052 
3053  /** Size of key_info_buffer array. */
3054  uint key_count;
3055 
3056  /** Size of index_drop_buffer array. */
3057  uint index_drop_count;
3058 
3059  /**
3060  Array of pointers to KEYs to be dropped belonging to the TABLE instance
3061  for the old version of the table.
3062  */
3063  KEY **index_drop_buffer;
3064 
3065  /** Size of index_add_buffer array. */
3066  uint index_add_count;
3067 
3068  /**
3069  Array of indexes into key_info_buffer for KEYs to be added,
3070  sorted in increasing order.
3071  */
3072  uint *index_add_buffer;
3073 
3074  /** Size of index_rename_buffer array. */
3075  uint index_rename_count;
3076 
3077  /** Size of index_rename_buffer array. */
3078  uint index_altered_visibility_count;
3079 
3080  /**
3081  Array of KEY_PAIR objects describing indexes being renamed.
3082  For each index renamed it contains object with KEY_PAIR::old_key
3083  pointing to KEY object belonging to the TABLE instance for old
3084  version of table representing old version of index and with
3085  KEY_PAIR::new_key pointing to KEY object for new version of
3086  index in key_info_buffer member.
3087  */
3088  KEY_PAIR *index_rename_buffer;
3089  KEY_PAIR *index_altered_visibility_buffer;
3090 
3091  /** Number of virtual columns to be added. */
3092  uint virtual_column_add_count;
3093 
3094  /** number of virtual columns to be dropped. */
3095  uint virtual_column_drop_count;
3096 
3097  /**
3098  Context information to allow handlers to keep context between in-place
3099  alter API calls.
3100 
3101  @see inplace_alter_handler_ctx for information about object lifecycle.
3102  */
3103  inplace_alter_handler_ctx *handler_ctx;
3104 
3105  /**
3106  If the table uses several handlers, like ha_partition uses one handler
3107  per partition, this contains a Null terminated array of ctx pointers
3108  that should all be committed together.
3109  Or NULL if only handler_ctx should be committed.
3110  Set to NULL if the low level handler::commit_inplace_alter_table uses it,
3111  to signal to the main handler that everything was committed as atomically.
3112 
3113  @see inplace_alter_handler_ctx for information about object lifecycle.
3114  */
3115  inplace_alter_handler_ctx **group_commit_ctx;
3116 
3117  /**
3118  Flags describing in detail which operations the storage engine is to
3119  execute.
3120  */
3121  HA_ALTER_FLAGS handler_flags;
3122 
3123  /**
3124  Partition_info taking into account the partition changes to be performed.
3125  Contains all partitions which are present in the old version of the table
3126  with partitions to be dropped or changed marked as such + all partitions
3127  to be added in the new version of table marked as such.
3128  */
3129  partition_info *modified_part_info;
3130 
3131  /** true for online operation (LOCK=NONE) */
3132  bool online;
3133 
3134  /**
3135  Can be set by handler along with handler_ctx. The difference is that
3136  this flag can be used to store SE-specific in-place ALTER context in cases
3137  when constructing full-blown inplace_alter_handler_ctx descendant is
3138  inconvenient.
3139  */
3140  uint handler_trivial_ctx;
3141 
3142  /**
3143  Can be set by handler to describe why a given operation cannot be done
3144  in-place (HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NOT_SUPPORTED) or why it cannot be done
3145  online (HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK or HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE)
3146  If set, it will be used with ER_ALTER_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED_REASON if
3147  results from handler::check_if_supported_inplace_alter() doesn't match
3148  requirements set by user. If not set, the more generic
3149  ER_ALTER_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED will be used.
3150 
3151  Please set to a properly localized string, for example using
3152  my_get_err_msg(), so that the error message as a whole is localized.
3153  */
3154  const char *unsupported_reason;
3155 
3156  Alter_inplace_info(HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info_arg,
3157  Alter_info *alter_info_arg, bool error_if_not_empty_arg,
3158  KEY *key_info_arg, uint key_count_arg,
3159  partition_info *modified_part_info_arg)
3160  : create_info(create_info_arg),
3161  alter_info(alter_info_arg),
3162  error_if_not_empty(error_if_not_empty_arg),
3163  key_info_buffer(key_info_arg),
3164  key_count(key_count_arg),
3165  index_drop_count(0),
3166  index_drop_buffer(nullptr),
3167  index_add_count(0),
3168  index_add_buffer(nullptr),
3169  index_rename_count(0),
3170  index_altered_visibility_count(0),
3171  index_rename_buffer(nullptr),
3172  virtual_column_add_count(0),
3173  virtual_column_drop_count(0),
3174  handler_ctx(nullptr),
3175  group_commit_ctx(nullptr),
3176  handler_flags(0),
3177  modified_part_info(modified_part_info_arg),
3178  online(false),
3179  handler_trivial_ctx(0),
3180  unsupported_reason(nullptr) {}
3181 
3182  ~Alter_inplace_info() { destroy(handler_ctx); }
3183 
3184  /**
3185  Used after check_if_supported_inplace_alter() to report
3186  error if the result does not match the LOCK/ALGORITHM
3187  requirements set by the user.
3188 
3189  @param not_supported Part of statement that was not supported.
3190  @param try_instead Suggestion as to what the user should
3191  replace not_supported with.
3192  */
3193  void report_unsupported_error(const char *not_supported,
3194  const char *try_instead);
3195 
3196  /** Add old and new version of key to array of indexes to be renamed. */
3197  void add_renamed_key(KEY *old_key, KEY *new_key) {
3198  KEY_PAIR *key_pair = index_rename_buffer + index_rename_count++;
3199  key_pair->old_key = old_key;
3200  key_pair->new_key = new_key;
3201  DBUG_PRINT("info",
3202  ("index renamed: '%s' to '%s'", old_key->name, new_key->name));
3203  }
3204 
3205  void add_altered_index_visibility(KEY *old_key, KEY *new_key) {
3206  KEY_PAIR *key_pair =
3207  index_altered_visibility_buffer + index_altered_visibility_count++;
3208  key_pair->old_key = old_key;
3209  key_pair->new_key = new_key;
3210  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("index had visibility altered: %i to %i",
3211  old_key->is_visible, new_key->is_visible));
3212  }
3213 
3214  /**
3215  Add old and new version of modified key to arrays of indexes to
3216  be dropped and added (correspondingly).
3217  */
3218  void add_modified_key(KEY *old_key, KEY *new_key) {
3219  index_drop_buffer[index_drop_count++] = old_key;
3220  index_add_buffer[index_add_count++] = (uint)(new_key - key_info_buffer);
3221  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("index changed: '%s'", old_key->name));
3222  }
3223 
3224  /** Drop key to array of indexes to be dropped. */
3225  void add_dropped_key(KEY *old_key) {
3226  index_drop_buffer[index_drop_count++] = old_key;
3227  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("index dropped: '%s'", old_key->name));
3228  }
3229 
3230  /** Add key to array of indexes to be added. */
3231  void add_added_key(KEY *new_key) {
3232  index_add_buffer[index_add_count++] = (uint)(new_key - key_info_buffer);
3233  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("index added: '%s'", new_key->name));
3234  }
3235 };
3236 
3237 struct HA_CHECK_OPT {
3238  uint flags{0}; /* isam layer flags (e.g. for myisamchk) */
3239  uint sql_flags{0}; /* sql layer flags - for something myisamchk cannot do */
3240  KEY_CACHE *key_cache; /* new key cache when changing key cache */
3241 };
3242 
3243 /*
3244  This is a buffer area that the handler can use to store rows.
3245  'end_of_used_area' should be kept updated after calls to
3246  read-functions so that other parts of the code can use the
3247  remaining area (until next read calls is issued).
3248 */
3249 
3250 struct HANDLER_BUFFER {
3251  uchar *buffer; /* Buffer one can start using */
3252  uchar *buffer_end; /* End of buffer */
3253  uchar *end_of_used_area; /* End of area that was used by handler */
3254 };
3255 
3256 typedef void *range_seq_t;
3257 
3258 struct RANGE_SEQ_IF {
3259  /*
3260  Initialize the traversal of range sequence
3261 
3262  SYNOPSIS
3263  init()
3264  init_params The seq_init_param parameter
3265  n_ranges The number of ranges obtained
3266  flags A combination of HA_MRR_SINGLE_POINT, HA_MRR_FIXED_KEY
3267 
3268  RETURN
3269  An opaque value to be used as RANGE_SEQ_IF::next() parameter
3270  */
3271  range_seq_t (*init)(void *init_params, uint n_ranges, uint flags);
3272 
3273  /*
3274  Get the next range in the range sequence
3275 
3276  SYNOPSIS
3277  next()
3278  seq The value returned by RANGE_SEQ_IF::init()
3279  range OUT Information about the next range
3280 
3281  RETURN
3282  0 - Ok, the range structure filled with info about the next range
3283  1 - No more ranges
3284  */
3285  uint (*next)(range_seq_t seq, KEY_MULTI_RANGE *range);
3286 
3287  /*
3288  Check whether range_info orders to skip the next record
3289 
3290  SYNOPSIS
3291  skip_record()
3292  seq The value returned by RANGE_SEQ_IF::init()
3293  range_info Information about the next range
3294  (Ignored if MRR_NO_ASSOCIATION is set)
3295  rowid Rowid of the record to be checked (ignored if set to 0)
3296 
3297  RETURN
3298  1 - Record with this range_info and/or this rowid shall be filtered
3299  out from the stream of records returned by ha_multi_range_read_next()
3300  0 - The record shall be left in the stream
3301  */
3302  bool (*skip_record)(range_seq_t seq, char *range_info, uchar *rowid);
3303 
3304  /*
3305  Check if the record combination matches the index condition
3306  SYNOPSIS
3307  skip_index_tuple()
3308  seq The value returned by RANGE_SEQ_IF::init()
3309  range_info Information about the next range
3310 
3311  RETURN
3312  0 - The record combination satisfies the index condition
3313  1 - Otherwise
3314  */
3315  bool (*skip_index_tuple)(range_seq_t seq, char *range_info);
3316 };
3317 
3318 /**
3319  Used to store optimizer cost estimates.
3320 
3321  The class consists of PODs only: default operator=, copy constructor
3322  and destructor are used.
3323  */
3324 class Cost_estimate {
3325  private:
3326  double io_cost; ///< cost of I/O operations
3327  double cpu_cost; ///< cost of CPU operations
3328  double import_cost; ///< cost of remote operations
3329  double mem_cost; ///< memory used (bytes)
3330 
3331  public:
3332  Cost_estimate() : io_cost(0), cpu_cost(0), import_cost(0), mem_cost(0) {}
3333 
3334  /// Returns sum of time-consuming costs, i.e., not counting memory cost
3335  double total_cost() const { return io_cost + cpu_cost + import_cost; }
3336  double get_io_cost() const { return io_cost; }
3337  double get_cpu_cost() const { return cpu_cost; }
3338  double get_import_cost() const { return import_cost; }
3339  double get_mem_cost() const { return mem_cost; }
3340 
3341  /**
3342  Whether or not all costs in the object are zero
3343 
3344  @return true if all costs are zero, false otherwise
3345  */
3346  bool is_zero() const {
3347  return !(io_cost || cpu_cost || import_cost || mem_cost);
3348  }
3349  /**
3350  Whether or not the total cost is the maximal double
3351 
3352  @return true if total cost is the maximal double, false otherwise
3353  */
3354  bool is_max_cost() const { return io_cost == DBL_MAX; }
3355  /// Reset all costs to zero
3356  void reset() { io_cost = cpu_cost = import_cost = mem_cost = 0; }
3357  /// Set current cost to the maximal double
3358  void set_max_cost() {
3359  reset();
3360  io_cost = DBL_MAX;
3361  }
3362 
3363  /// Multiply io, cpu and import costs by parameter
3364  void multiply(double m) {
3365  DBUG_ASSERT(!is_max_cost());
3366 
3367  io_cost *= m;
3368  cpu_cost *= m;
3369  import_cost *= m;
3370  /* Don't multiply mem_cost */
3371  }
3372 
3373  Cost_estimate &operator+=(const Cost_estimate &other) {
3374  DBUG_ASSERT(!is_max_cost() && !other.is_max_cost());
3375 
3376  io_cost += other.io_cost;
3377  cpu_cost += other.cpu_cost;
3378  import_cost += other.import_cost;
3379  mem_cost += other.mem_cost;
3380 
3381  return *this;
3382  }
3383 
3384  Cost_estimate operator+(const Cost_estimate &other) {
3385  Cost_estimate result = *this;
3386  result += other;
3387 
3388  return result;
3389  }
3390 
3391  Cost_estimate operator-(const Cost_estimate &other) {
3392  Cost_estimate result;
3393 
3394  DBUG_ASSERT(!other.is_max_cost());
3395 
3396  result.io_cost = io_cost - other.io_cost;
3397  result.cpu_cost = cpu_cost - other.cpu_cost;
3398  result.import_cost = import_cost - other.import_cost;
3399  result.mem_cost = mem_cost - other.mem_cost;
3400  return result;
3401  }
3402 
3403  bool operator>(const Cost_estimate &other) const {
3404  return total_cost() > other.total_cost() ? true : false;
3405  }
3406 
3407  bool operator<(const Cost_estimate &other) const {
3408  return other > *this ? true : false;
3409  }
3410 
3411  /// Add to IO cost
3412  void add_io(double add_io_cost) {
3413  DBUG_ASSERT(!is_max_cost());
3414  io_cost += add_io_cost;
3415  }
3416 
3417  /// Add to CPU cost
3418  void add_cpu(double add_cpu_cost) {
3419  DBUG_ASSERT(!is_max_cost());
3420  cpu_cost += add_cpu_cost;
3421  }
3422 
3423  /// Add to import cost
3424  void add_import(double add_import_cost) {
3425  DBUG_ASSERT(!is_max_cost());
3426  import_cost += add_import_cost;
3427  }
3428 
3429  /// Add to memory cost
3430  void add_mem(double add_mem_cost) {
3431  DBUG_ASSERT(!is_max_cost());
3432  mem_cost += add_mem_cost;
3433  }
3434 };
3435 
3436 void get_sweep_read_cost(TABLE *table, ha_rows nrows, bool interrupted,
3437  Cost_estimate *cost);
3438 
3439 /*
3440  The below two are not used (and not handled) in this milestone of this WL
3441  entry because there seems to be no use for them at this stage of
3442  implementation.
3443 */
3444 #define HA_MRR_SINGLE_POINT 1
3445 #define HA_MRR_FIXED_KEY 2
3446 
3447 /*
3448  Indicates that RANGE_SEQ_IF::next(&range) doesn't need to fill in the
3449  'range' parameter.
3450 */
3451 #define HA_MRR_NO_ASSOCIATION 4
3452 
3453 /*
3454  The MRR user will provide ranges in key order, and MRR implementation
3455  must return rows in key order.
3456  Passing this flag to multi_read_range_init() may cause the
3457  default MRR handler to be used even if HA_MRR_USE_DEFAULT_IMPL
3458  was not specified.
3459  (If the native MRR impl. can not provide SORTED result)
3460 */
3461 #define HA_MRR_SORTED 8
3462 
3463 /* MRR implementation doesn't have to retrieve full records */
3464 #define HA_MRR_INDEX_ONLY 16
3465 
3466 /*
3467  The passed memory buffer is of maximum possible size, the caller can't
3468  assume larger buffer.
3469 */
3470 #define HA_MRR_LIMITS 32
3471 
3472 /*
3473  Flag set <=> default MRR implementation is used
3474  (The choice is made by **_info[_const]() function which may set this
3475  flag. SQL layer remembers the flag value and then passes it to
3476  multi_read_range_init().
3477 */
3478 #define HA_MRR_USE_DEFAULT_IMPL 64
3479 
3480 /*
3481  Used only as parameter to multi_range_read_info():
3482  Flag set <=> the caller guarantees that the bounds of the scanned ranges
3483  will not have NULL values.
3484 */
3485 #define HA_MRR_NO_NULL_ENDPOINTS 128
3486 
3487 /*
3488  Set by the MRR implementation to signal that it will natively
3489  produced sorted result if multi_range_read_init() is called with
3490  the HA_MRR_SORTED flag - Else multi_range_read_init(HA_MRR_SORTED)
3491  will revert to use the default MRR implementation.
3492 */
3493 #define HA_MRR_SUPPORT_SORTED 256
3494 
3495 class ha_statistics {
3496  public:
3497  ulonglong data_file_length; /* Length off data file */
3498  ulonglong max_data_file_length; /* Length off data file */
3499  ulonglong index_file_length;
3500  ulonglong max_index_file_length;
3501  ulonglong delete_length; /* Free bytes */
3502  ulonglong auto_increment_value;
3503  /*
3504  The number of records in the table.
3505  0 - means the table has exactly 0 rows
3506  other - if (table_flags() & HA_STATS_RECORDS_IS_EXACT)
3507  the value is the exact number of records in the table
3508  else
3509  it is an estimate
3510  */
3511  ha_rows records;
3512  ha_rows deleted; /* Deleted records */
3513  ulong mean_rec_length; /* physical reclength */
3514  /* TODO: create_time should be retrieved from the new DD. Remove this. */
3515  time_t create_time; /* When table was created */
3516  ulong check_time;
3517  ulong update_time;
3518  uint block_size; /* index block size */
3519 
3520  /*
3521  number of buffer bytes that native mrr implementation needs,
3522  */
3523  uint mrr_length_per_rec;
3524 
3525  /**
3526  Estimate for how much of the table that is availabe in a memory
3527  buffer. Valid range is [0..1]. If it has the special value
3528  IN_MEMORY_ESTIMATE_UNKNOWN (defined in structs.h), it means that
3529  the storage engine has not supplied any value for it.
3530  */
3531  double table_in_mem_estimate;
3532 
3533  ha_statistics()
3534  : data_file_length(0),
3535  max_data_file_length(0),
3536  index_file_length(0),
3537  delete_length(0),
3538  auto_increment_value(0),
3539  records(0),
3540  deleted(0),
3541  mean_rec_length(0),
3542  create_time(0),
3543  check_time(0),
3544  update_time(0),
3545  block_size(0),
3546  table_in_mem_estimate(IN_MEMORY_ESTIMATE_UNKNOWN) {}
3547 };
3548 
3549 /**
3550  Calculates length of key.
3551 
3552  Given a key index and a map of key parts return length of buffer used by key
3553  parts.
3554 
3555  @param table Table containing the key
3556  @param key Key index
3557  @param keypart_map which key parts that is used
3558 
3559  @return Length of used key parts.
3560 */
3561 uint calculate_key_len(TABLE *table, uint key, key_part_map keypart_map);
3562 /*
3563  bitmap with first N+1 bits set
3564  (keypart_map for a key prefix of [0..N] keyparts)
3565 */
3566 #define make_keypart_map(N) (((key_part_map)2 << (N)) - 1)
3567 /*
3568  bitmap with first N bits set
3569  (keypart_map for a key prefix of [0..N-1] keyparts)
3570 */
3571 #define make_prev_keypart_map(N) (((key_part_map)1 << (N)) - 1)
3572 
3573 /** Base class to be used by handlers different shares */
3574 class Handler_share {
3575  public:
3576  Handler_share() {}
3577  virtual ~Handler_share() {}
3578 };
3579 
3580 /**
3581  Wrapper for struct ft_hints.
3582 */
3583 
3584 class Ft_hints {
3585  private:
3586  struct ft_hints hints;
3587 
3588  public:
3589  Ft_hints(uint ft_flags) {
3590  hints.flags = ft_flags;
3591  hints.op_type = FT_OP_UNDEFINED;
3592  hints.op_value = 0.0;
3593  hints.limit = HA_POS_ERROR;
3594  }
3595 
3596  /**
3597  Set comparison operation type and and value for master MATCH function.
3598 
3599  @param type comparison operation type
3600  @param value comparison operation value
3601  */
3602  void set_hint_op(enum ft_operation type, double value) {
3603  hints.op_type = type;
3604  hints.op_value = value;
3605  }
3606 
3607  /**
3608  Set Ft_hints flag.
3609 
3610  @param ft_flag Ft_hints flag
3611  */
3612  void set_hint_flag(uint ft_flag) { hints.flags |= ft_flag; }
3613 
3614  /**
3615  Set Ft_hints limit.
3616 
3617  @param ft_limit limit
3618  */
3619  void set_hint_limit(ha_rows ft_limit) { hints.limit = ft_limit; }
3620 
3621  /**
3622  Get Ft_hints limit.
3623 
3624  @return Ft_hints limit
3625  */
3626  ha_rows get_limit() { return hints.limit; }
3627 
3628  /**
3629  Get Ft_hints operation value.
3630 
3631  @return operation value
3632  */
3633  double get_op_value() { return hints.op_value; }
3634 
3635  /**
3636  Get Ft_hints operation type.
3637 
3638  @return operation type
3639  */
3640  enum ft_operation get_op_type() { return hints.op_type; }
3641 
3642  /**
3643  Get Ft_hints flags.
3644 
3645  @return Ft_hints flags
3646  */
3647  uint get_flags() { return hints.flags; }
3648 
3649  /**
3650  Get ft_hints struct.
3651 
3652  @return pointer to ft_hints struct
3653  */
3654  struct ft_hints *get_hints() {
3655  return &hints;
3656  }
3657 };
3658 
3659 /**
3660  The handler class is the interface for dynamically loadable
3661  storage engines. Do not add ifdefs and take care when adding or
3662  changing virtual functions to avoid vtable confusion
3663 
3664  Functions in this class accept and return table columns data. Two data
3665  representation formats are used:
3666  1. TableRecordFormat - Used to pass [partial] table records to/from
3667  storage engine
3668 
3669  2. KeyTupleFormat - used to pass index search tuples (aka "keys") to
3670  storage engine. See opt_range.cc for description of this format.
3671 
3672  TableRecordFormat
3673  =================
3674  [Warning: this description is work in progress and may be incomplete]
3675  The table record is stored in a fixed-size buffer:
3676 
3677  record: null_bytes, column1_data, column2_data, ...
3678 
3679  The offsets of the parts of the buffer are also fixed: every column has
3680  an offset to its column{i}_data, and if it is nullable it also has its own
3681  bit in null_bytes.
3682 
3683  The record buffer only includes data about columns that are marked in the
3684  relevant column set (table->read_set and/or table->write_set, depending on
3685  the situation).
3686  <not-sure>It could be that it is required that null bits of non-present
3687  columns are set to 1</not-sure>
3688 
3689  VARIOUS EXCEPTIONS AND SPECIAL CASES
3690 
3691  If the table has no nullable columns, then null_bytes is still
3692  present, its length is one byte <not-sure> which must be set to 0xFF
3693  at all times. </not-sure>
3694 
3695  If the table has columns of type BIT, then certain bits from those columns
3696  may be stored in null_bytes as well. Grep around for Field_bit for
3697  details.
3698 
3699  For blob columns (see Field_blob), the record buffer stores length of the
3700  data, following by memory pointer to the blob data. The pointer is owned
3701  by the storage engine and is valid until the next operation.
3702 
3703  If a blob column has NULL value, then its length and blob data pointer
3704  must be set to 0.
3705 
3706 
3707  Overview of main modules of the handler API
3708  ===========================================
3709  The overview below was copied from the storage/partition/ha_partition.h when
3710  support for non-native partitioning was removed.
3711 
3712  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3713  MODULE create/delete handler object
3714  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3715  Object create/delete method. Normally called when a table object
3716  exists.
3717 
3718  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3719  MODULE meta data changes
3720  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3721  Meta data routines to CREATE, DROP, RENAME table are often used at
3722  ALTER TABLE (update_create_info used from ALTER TABLE and SHOW ..).
3723 
3724  Methods:
3725  delete_table()
3726  rename_table()
3727  create()
3728  update_create_info()
3729 
3730  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3731  MODULE open/close object
3732  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3733  Open and close handler object to ensure all underlying files and
3734  objects allocated and deallocated for query handling is handled
3735  properly.
3736 
3737  A handler object is opened as part of its initialisation and before
3738  being used for normal queries (not before meta-data changes always.
3739  If the object was opened it will also be closed before being deleted.
3740 
3741  Methods:
3742  open()
3743  close()
3744 
3745  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3746  MODULE start/end statement
3747  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3748  This module contains methods that are used to understand start/end of
3749  statements, transaction boundaries, and aid for proper concurrency
3750  control.
3751 
3752  Methods:
3753  store_lock()
3754  external_lock()
3755  start_stmt()
3756  lock_count()
3757  unlock_row()
3758  was_semi_consistent_read()
3759  try_semi_consistent_read()
3760 
3761  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3762  MODULE change record
3763  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3764  This part of the handler interface is used to change the records
3765  after INSERT, DELETE, UPDATE, REPLACE method calls but also other
3766  special meta-data operations as ALTER TABLE, LOAD DATA, TRUNCATE.
3767 
3768  These methods are used for insert (write_row), update (update_row)
3769  and delete (delete_row). All methods to change data always work on
3770  one row at a time. update_row and delete_row also contains the old
3771  row.
3772  delete_all_rows will delete all rows in the table in one call as a
3773  special optimization for DELETE from table;
3774 
3775  Bulk inserts are supported if all underlying handlers support it.
3776  start_bulk_insert and end_bulk_insert is called before and after a
3777  number of calls to write_row.
3778 
3779  Methods:
3780  write_row()
3781  update_row()
3782  delete_row()
3783  delete_all_rows()
3784  start_bulk_insert()
3785  end_bulk_insert()
3786 
3787  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3788  MODULE full table scan
3789  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3790  This module is used for the most basic access method for any table
3791  handler. This is to fetch all data through a full table scan. No
3792  indexes are needed to implement this part.
3793  It contains one method to start the scan (rnd_init) that can also be
3794  called multiple times (typical in a nested loop join). Then proceeding
3795  to the next record (rnd_next) and closing the scan (rnd_end).
3796  To remember a record for later access there is a method (position)
3797  and there is a method used to retrieve the record based on the stored
3798  position.
3799  The position can be a file position, a primary key, a ROWID dependent
3800  on the handler below.
3801 
3802  All functions that retrieve records and are callable through the
3803  handler interface must indicate whether a record is present after the call
3804  or not. Record found is indicated by returning 0 and setting table status
3805  to "has row". Record not found is indicated by returning a non-zero value
3806  and setting table status to "no row".
3807  @see TABLE::set_found_row() and TABLE::set_no_row().
3808  By enforcing these rules in the handler interface, storage handler functions
3809  need not set any status in struct TABLE. These notes also apply to module
3810  index scan, documented below.
3811 
3812  Methods:
3813 
3814  rnd_init()
3815  rnd_end()
3816  rnd_next()
3817  rnd_pos()
3818  rnd_pos_by_record()
3819  position()
3820 
3821  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3822  MODULE index scan
3823  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3824  This part of the handler interface is used to perform access through
3825  indexes. The interface is defined as a scan interface but the handler
3826  can also use key lookup if the index is a unique index or a primary
3827  key index.
3828  Index scans are mostly useful for SELECT queries but are an important
3829  part also of UPDATE, DELETE, REPLACE and CREATE TABLE table AS SELECT
3830  and so forth.
3831  Naturally an index is needed for an index scan and indexes can either
3832  be ordered, hash based. Some ordered indexes can return data in order
3833  but not necessarily all of them.
3834  There are many flags that define the behavior of indexes in the
3835  various handlers. These methods are found in the optimizer module.
3836 
3837  index_read is called to start a scan of an index. The find_flag defines
3838  the semantics of the scan. These flags are defined in
3839  include/my_base.h
3840  index_read_idx is the same but also initializes index before calling doing
3841  the same thing as index_read. Thus it is similar to index_init followed
3842  by index_read. This is also how we implement it.
3843 
3844  index_read/index_read_idx does also return the first row. Thus for
3845  key lookups, the index_read will be the only call to the handler in
3846  the index scan.
3847 
3848  index_init initializes an index before using it and index_end does
3849  any end processing needed.
3850 
3851  Methods:
3852  index_read_map()
3853  index_init()
3854  index_end()
3855  index_read_idx_map()
3856  index_next()
3857  index_prev()
3858  index_first()
3859  index_last()
3860  index_next_same()
3861  index_read_last_map()
3862  read_range_first()
3863  read_range_next()
3864 
3865  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3866  MODULE information calls
3867  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3868  This calls are used to inform the handler of specifics of the ongoing
3869  scans and other actions. Most of these are used for optimisation
3870  purposes.
3871 
3872  Methods:
3873  info()
3874  get_dynamic_partition_info
3875  extra()
3876  extra_opt()
3877  reset()
3878 
3879  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3880  MODULE optimizer support
3881  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3882  NOTE:
3883  One important part of the public handler interface that is not depicted in
3884  the methods is the attribute records which is defined in the base class.
3885  This is looked upon directly and is set by calling info(HA_STATUS_INFO) ?
3886 
3887  Methods:
3888  min_rows_for_estimate()
3889  get_biggest_used_partition()
3890  scan_time()
3891  read_time()
3892  records_in_range()
3893  estimate_rows_upper_bound()
3894  records()
3895 
3896  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3897  MODULE print messages
3898  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3899  This module contains various methods that returns text messages for
3900  table types, index type and error messages.
3901 
3902  Methods:
3903  table_type()
3904  get_row_type()
3905  print_error()
3906  get_error_message()
3907 
3908  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3909  MODULE handler characteristics
3910  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3911  This module contains a number of methods defining limitations and
3912  characteristics of the handler (see also documentation regarding the
3913  individual flags).
3914 
3915  Methods:
3916  table_flags()
3917  index_flags()
3918  min_of_the_max_uint()
3919  max_supported_record_length()
3920  max_supported_keys()
3921  max_supported_key_parts()
3922  max_supported_key_length()
3923  max_supported_key_part_length()
3924  low_byte_first()
3925  extra_rec_buf_length()
3926  min_record_length(uint options)
3927  primary_key_is_clustered()
3928  ha_key_alg get_default_index_algorithm()
3929  is_index_algorithm_supported()
3930 
3931  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3932  MODULE compare records
3933  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3934  cmp_ref checks if two references are the same. For most handlers this is
3935  a simple memcmp of the reference. However some handlers use primary key
3936  as reference and this can be the same even if memcmp says they are
3937  different. This is due to character sets and end spaces and so forth.
3938 
3939  Methods:
3940  cmp_ref()
3941 
3942  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3943  MODULE auto increment
3944  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3945  This module is used to handle the support of auto increments.
3946 
3947  This variable in the handler is used as part of the handler interface
3948  It is maintained by the parent handler object and should not be
3949  touched by child handler objects (see handler.cc for its use).
3950 
3951  Methods:
3952  get_auto_increment()
3953  release_auto_increment()
3954 
3955  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3956  MODULE initialize handler for HANDLER call
3957  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3958  This method is a special InnoDB method called before a HANDLER query.
3959 
3960  Methods:
3961  init_table_handle_for_HANDLER()
3962 
3963  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3964  MODULE fulltext index
3965  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3966  Fulltext index support.
3967 
3968  Methods:
3969  ft_init_ext_with_hints()
3970  ft_init()
3971  ft_init_ext()
3972  ft_read()
3973 
3974  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3975  MODULE in-place ALTER TABLE
3976  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3977  Methods for in-place ALTER TABLE support (implemented by InnoDB and NDB).
3978 
3979  Methods:
3980  check_if_supported_inplace_alter()
3981  prepare_inplace_alter_table()
3982  inplace_alter_table()
3983  commit_inplace_alter_table()
3984  notify_table_changed()
3985 
3986  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3987  MODULE tablespace support
3988  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3989  Methods:
3990  discard_or_import_tablespace()
3991 
3992  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3993  MODULE administrative DDL
3994  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
3995  Methods:
3996  optimize()
3997  analyze()
3998  check()
3999  repair()
4000  check_and_repair()
4001  auto_repair()
4002  is_crashed()
4003  check_for_upgrade()
4004  checksum()
4005  assign_to_keycache()
4006 
4007  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4008  MODULE enable/disable indexes
4009  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4010  Enable/Disable Indexes are only supported by HEAP and MyISAM.
4011 
4012  Methods:
4013  disable_indexes()
4014  enable_indexes()
4015  indexes_are_disabled()
4016 
4017  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4018  MODULE append_create_info
4019  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4020  Only used by MyISAM MERGE tables.
4021 
4022  Methods:
4023  append_create_info()
4024 
4025  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4026  MODULE partitioning specific handler API
4027  -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4028  Methods:
4029  get_partition_handler()
4030 */
4031 
4032 class handler {
4033  friend class Partition_handler;
4034 
4035  public:
4036  typedef ulonglong Table_flags;
4037 
4038  protected:
4039  TABLE_SHARE *table_share; /* The table definition */
4040  TABLE *table; /* The current open table */
4041  Table_flags cached_table_flags; /* Set on init() and open() */
4042 
4043  ha_rows estimation_rows_to_insert;
4044 
4045  public:
4046  handlerton *ht; /* storage engine of this handler */
4047  /** Pointer to current row */
4048  uchar *ref;
4049  /** Pointer to duplicate row */
4050  uchar *dup_ref;
4051 
4052  ha_statistics stats;
4053 
4054  /* MultiRangeRead-related members: */
4055  range_seq_t mrr_iter; /* Interator to traverse the range sequence */
4056  RANGE_SEQ_IF mrr_funcs; /* Range sequence traversal functions */
4057  HANDLER_BUFFER *multi_range_buffer; /* MRR buffer info */
4058  uint ranges_in_seq; /* Total number of ranges in the traversed sequence */
4059  /* true <=> source MRR ranges and the output are ordered */
4060  bool mrr_is_output_sorted;
4061 
4062  /* true <=> we're currently traversing a range in mrr_cur_range. */
4063  bool mrr_have_range;
4064  /* Current range (the one we're now returning rows from) */
4065  KEY_MULTI_RANGE mrr_cur_range;
4066 
4067  /*
4068  The direction of the current range or index scan. This is used by
4069  the ICP implementation to determine if it has reached the end
4070  of the current range.
4071  */
4072  enum enum_range_scan_direction { RANGE_SCAN_ASC, RANGE_SCAN_DESC };
4073 
4074  private:
4075  Record_buffer *m_record_buffer = nullptr; ///< Buffer for multi-row reads.
4076  /*
4077  Storage space for the end range value. Should only be accessed using
4078  the end_range pointer. The content is invalid when end_range is NULL.
4079  */
4080  key_range save_end_range;
4081  enum_range_scan_direction range_scan_direction;
4082  int key_compare_result_on_equal;
4083 
4084  /**
4085  Pointer to the handler of the table in the primary storage engine,
4086  if this handler represents a table in a secondary storage engine.
4087  */
4088  handler *m_primary_handler{nullptr};
4089 
4090  protected:
4091  KEY_PART_INFO *range_key_part;
4092  bool eq_range;
4093  /*
4094  true <=> the engine guarantees that returned records are within the range
4095  being scanned.
4096  */
4097  bool in_range_check_pushed_down;
4098 
4099  public:
4100  /**
4101  End value for a range scan. If this is NULL the range scan has no
4102  end value. Should also be NULL when there is no ongoing range scan.
4103  Used by the read_range() functions and also evaluated by pushed
4104  index conditions.
4105  */
4106  key_range *end_range;
4107  /**
4108  Flag which tells if #end_range contains a virtual generated column.
4109  The content is invalid when #end_range is @c nullptr.
4110  */
4111  bool m_virt_gcol_in_end_range = false;
4112  uint errkey; /* Last dup key */
4113  uint key_used_on_scan;
4114  uint active_index;
4115  /** Length of ref (1-8 or the clustered key length) */
4116  uint ref_length;
4117  FT_INFO *ft_handler;
4118  enum { NONE = 0, INDEX, RND, SAMPLING } inited;
4119  bool implicit_emptied; /* Can be !=0 only if HEAP */
4120  const Item *pushed_cond;
4121 
4122  Item *pushed_idx_cond;
4123  uint pushed_idx_cond_keyno; /* The index which the above condition is for */
4124 
4125  /**
4126  next_insert_id is the next value which should be inserted into the
4127  auto_increment column: in a inserting-multi-row statement (like INSERT
4128  SELECT), for the first row where the autoinc value is not specified by the
4129  statement, get_auto_increment() called and asked to generate a value,
4130  next_insert_id is set to the next value, then for all other rows
4131  next_insert_id is used (and increased each time) without calling
4132  get_auto_increment().
4133  */
4134  ulonglong next_insert_id;
4135  /**
4136  insert id for the current row (*autogenerated*; if not
4137  autogenerated, it's 0).
4138  At first successful insertion, this variable is stored into
4139  THD::first_successful_insert_id_in_cur_stmt.
4140  */
4141  ulonglong insert_id_for_cur_row;
4142  /**
4143  Interval returned by get_auto_increment() and being consumed by the
4144  inserter.
4145  */
4146  Discrete_interval auto_inc_interval_for_cur_row;
4147  /**
4148  Number of reserved auto-increment intervals. Serves as a heuristic
4149  when we have no estimation of how many records the statement will insert:
4150  the more intervals we have reserved, the bigger the next one. Reset in
4151  handler::ha_release_auto_increment().
4152  */
4153  uint auto_inc_intervals_count;
4154 
4155  /**
4156  Instrumented table associated with this handler.
4157  */
4158  PSI_table *m_psi;
4159 
4160  std::mt19937 m_random_number_engine;
4161  double m_sampling_percentage;
4162 
4163  private:
4164  /** Internal state of the batch instrumentation. */
4165  enum batch_mode_t {
4166  /** Batch mode not used. */
4167  PSI_BATCH_MODE_NONE,
4168  /** Batch mode used, before first table io. */
4169  PSI_BATCH_MODE_STARTING,
4170  /** Batch mode used, after first table io. */
4171  PSI_BATCH_MODE_STARTED
4172  };
4173  /**
4174  Batch mode state.
4175  @sa start_psi_batch_mode.
4176  @sa end_psi_batch_mode.
4177  */
4178  batch_mode_t m_psi_batch_mode;
4179  /**
4180  The number of rows in the batch.
4181  @sa start_psi_batch_mode.
4182  @sa end_psi_batch_mode.
4183  */
4184  ulonglong m_psi_numrows;
4185  /**
4186  The current event in a batch.
4187  @sa start_psi_batch_mode.
4188  @sa end_psi_batch_mode.
4189  */
4190  PSI_table_locker *m_psi_locker;
4191  /**
4192  Storage for the event in a batch.
4193  @sa start_psi_batch_mode.
4194  @sa end_psi_batch_mode.
4195  */
4196  PSI_table_locker_state m_psi_locker_state;
4197 
4198  public:
4199  void unbind_psi();
4200  void rebind_psi();
4201  /**
4202  Put the handler in 'batch' mode when collecting
4203  table io instrumented events.
4204  When operating in batch mode:
4205  - a single start event is generated in the performance schema.
4206  - all table io performed between @c start_psi_batch_mode
4207  and @c end_psi_batch_mode is not instrumented:
4208  the number of rows affected is counted instead in @c m_psi_numrows.
4209  - a single end event is generated in the performance schema
4210  when the batch mode ends with @c end_psi_batch_mode.
4211  */
4212  void start_psi_batch_mode();
4213  /** End a batch started with @c start_psi_batch_mode. */
4214  void end_psi_batch_mode();
4215  /**
4216  If a PSI batch was started, turn if off.
4217  @returns true if it was started.
4218  */
4219  bool end_psi_batch_mode_if_started() {
4220  bool rc = m_psi_batch_mode;
4221  if (rc) end_psi_batch_mode();
4222  return rc;
4223  }
4224 
4225  private:
4226  /**
4227  The lock type set by when calling::ha_external_lock(). This is
4228  propagated down to the storage engine. The reason for also storing
4229  it here, is that when doing MRR we need to create/clone a second handler
4230  object. This cloned handler object needs to know about the lock_type used.
4231  */
4232  int m_lock_type;
4233  /**
4234  Pointer where to store/retrieve the Handler_share pointer.
4235  For non partitioned handlers this is &TABLE_SHARE::ha_share.
4236  */
4237  Handler_share **ha_share;
4238 
4239  /**
4240  Some non-virtual ha_* functions, responsible for reading rows,
4241  like ha_rnd_pos(), must ensure that virtual generated columns are
4242  calculated before they return. For that, they should set this
4243  member to true at their start, and check it before they return: if
4244  the member is still true, it means they should calculate; if it's
4245  false, it means the calculation has been done by some called
4246  lower-level function and does not need to be re-done (which is why
4247  we need this status flag: to avoid redundant calculations, for
4248  performance).
4249 
4250  Note that when updating generated fields, the NULL row status in
4251  the underlying TABLE objects matter, so be sure to reset them if needed!
4252  */
4253  bool m_update_generated_read_fields;
4254 
4255  /* Filter row ids to weed out duplicates when multi-valued index is used */
4256  Unique_on_insert *m_unique;
4257 
4258  public:
4259  handler(handlerton *ht_arg, TABLE_SHARE *share_arg)
4260  : table_share(share_arg),
4261  table(nullptr),
4262  estimation_rows_to_insert(0),
4263  ht(ht_arg),
4264  ref(nullptr),
4265  range_scan_direction(RANGE_SCAN_ASC),
4266  in_range_check_pushed_down(false),
4267  end_range(nullptr),
4268  key_used_on_scan(MAX_KEY),
4269  active_index(MAX_KEY),
4270  ref_length(sizeof(my_off_t)),
4271  ft_handler(nullptr),
4272  inited(NONE),
4273  implicit_emptied(false),
4274  pushed_cond(nullptr),
4275  pushed_idx_cond(nullptr),
4276  pushed_idx_cond_keyno(MAX_KEY),
4277  next_insert_id(0),
4278  insert_id_for_cur_row(0),
4279  auto_inc_intervals_count(0),
4280  m_psi(nullptr),
4281  m_psi_batch_mode(PSI_BATCH_MODE_NONE),
4282  m_psi_numrows(0),
4283  m_psi_locker(nullptr),
4284  m_lock_type(F_UNLCK),
4285  ha_share(nullptr),
4286  m_update_generated_read_fields(false),
4287  m_unique(nullptr) {
4288  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("handler created F_UNLCK %d F_RDLCK %d F_WRLCK %d",
4289  F_UNLCK, F_RDLCK, F_WRLCK));
4290  }
4291 
4292  virtual ~handler(void) {
4293  DBUG_ASSERT(m_psi == nullptr);
4294  DBUG_ASSERT(m_psi_batch_mode == PSI_BATCH_MODE_NONE);
4295  DBUG_ASSERT(m_psi_locker == nullptr);
4296  DBUG_ASSERT(m_lock_type == F_UNLCK);
4297  DBUG_ASSERT(inited == NONE);
4298  }
4299 
4300  /**
4301  Return extra handler specific text for EXPLAIN.
4302  */
4303  virtual std::string explain_extra() const { return ""; }
4304 
4305  /*
4306  @todo reorganize functions, make proper public/protected/private qualifiers
4307  */
4308  virtual handler *clone(const char *name, MEM_ROOT *mem_root);
4309  /** This is called after create to allow us to set up cached variables */
4310  void init() { cached_table_flags = table_flags(); }
4311  /* ha_ methods: public wrappers for private virtual API */
4312 
4313  /**
4314  Set a record buffer that the storage engine can use for multi-row reads.
4315  The buffer has to be provided prior to the first read from an index or a
4316  table.
4317 
4318  @param buffer the buffer to use for multi-row reads
4319  */
4320  void ha_set_record_buffer(Record_buffer *buffer) { m_record_buffer = buffer; }
4321 
4322  /**
4323  Get the record buffer that was set with ha_set_record_buffer().
4324 
4325  @return the buffer to use for multi-row reads, or nullptr if there is none
4326  */
4327  Record_buffer *ha_get_record_buffer() const { return m_record_buffer; }
4328 
4329  /**
4330  Does this handler want to get a Record_buffer for multi-row reads
4331  via the ha_set_record_buffer() function? And if so, what is the
4332  maximum number of records to allocate space for in the buffer?
4333 
4334  Storage engines that support using a Record_buffer should override
4335  handler::is_record_buffer_wanted().
4336 
4337  @param[out] max_rows gets set to the maximum number of records to
4338  allocate space for in the buffer if the function
4339  returns true
4340 
4341  @retval true if the handler would like a Record_buffer
4342  @retval false if the handler does not want a Record_buffer
4343  */
4344  bool ha_is_record_buffer_wanted(ha_rows *const max_rows) const {
4345  return is_record_buffer_wanted(max_rows);
4346  }
4347 
4348  int ha_open(TABLE *table, const char *name, int mode, int test_if_locked,
4349  const dd::Table *table_def);
4350  int ha_close(void);
4351  int ha_index_init(uint idx, bool sorted);
4352  int ha_index_end();
4353  int ha_rnd_init(bool scan);
4354  int ha_rnd_end();
4355  int ha_rnd_next(uchar *buf);
4356  // See the comment on m_update_generated_read_fields.
4357  int ha_rnd_pos(uchar *buf, uchar *pos);
4358  int ha_index_read_map(uchar *buf, const uchar *key, key_part_map keypart_map,
4359  enum ha_rkey_function find_flag);
4360  int ha_index_read_last_map(uchar *buf, const uchar *key,
4361  key_part_map keypart_map);
4362  int ha_index_read_idx_map(uchar *buf, uint index, const uchar *key,
4363  key_part_map keypart_map,
4364  enum ha_rkey_function find_flag);
4365  int ha_index_next(uchar *buf);
4366  int ha_index_prev(uchar *buf);
4367  int ha_index_first(uchar *buf);
4368  int ha_index_last(uchar *buf);
4369  int ha_index_next_same(uchar *buf, const uchar *key, uint keylen);
4370  int ha_reset();
4371  /* this is necessary in many places, e.g. in HANDLER command */
4372  int ha_index_or_rnd_end() {
4373  return inited == INDEX ? ha_index_end() : inited == RND ? ha_rnd_end() : 0;
4374  }
4375  /**
4376  The cached_table_flags is set at ha_open and ha_external_lock
4377  */
4378  Table_flags ha_table_flags() const { return cached_table_flags; }
4379  /**
4380  These functions represent the public interface to *users* of the
4381  handler class, hence they are *not* virtual. For the inheritance
4382  interface, see the (private) functions write_row(), update_row(),
4383  and delete_row() below.
4384  */
4385  int ha_external_lock(THD *thd, int lock_type);
4386  int ha_write_row(uchar *buf);
4387  /**
4388  Update the current row.
4389 
4390  @param old_data the old contents of the row
4391  @param new_data the new contents of the row
4392  @return error status (zero on success, HA_ERR_* error code on error)
4393  */
4394  int ha_update_row(const uchar *old_data, uchar *new_data);
4395  int ha_delete_row(const uchar *buf);
4396  void ha_release_auto_increment();
4397 
4398  int ha_check_for_upgrade(HA_CHECK_OPT *check_opt);
4399  /** to be actually called to get 'check()' functionality*/
4400  int ha_check(THD *thd, HA_CHECK_OPT *check_opt);
4401  int ha_repair(THD *thd, HA_CHECK_OPT *check_opt);
4402  void ha_start_bulk_insert(ha_rows rows);
4403  int ha_end_bulk_insert();
4404  int ha_bulk_update_row(const uchar *old_data, uchar *new_data,
4405  uint *dup_key_found);
4406  int ha_delete_all_rows();
4407  int ha_truncate(dd::Table *table_def);
4408  int ha_optimize(THD *thd, HA_CHECK_OPT *check_opt);
4409  int ha_analyze(THD *thd, HA_CHECK_OPT *check_opt);
4410  bool ha_check_and_repair(THD *thd);
4411  int ha_disable_indexes(uint mode);
4412  int ha_enable_indexes(uint mode);
4413  int ha_discard_or_import_tablespace(bool discard, dd::Table *table_def);
4414  int ha_rename_table(const char *from, const char *to,
4415  const dd::Table *from_table_def, dd::Table *to_table_def);
4416  int ha_delete_table(const char *name, const dd::Table *table_def);
4417  void ha_drop_table(const char *name);
4418 
4419  int ha_create(const char *name, TABLE *form, HA_CREATE_INFO *info,
4420  dd::Table *table_def);
4421 
4422  int ha_load_table(const TABLE &table);
4423 
4424  int ha_unload_table(const char *db_name, const char *table_name,
4425  bool error_if_not_loaded);
4426 
4427  /**
4428  Initializes a parallel scan. It creates a parallel_scan_ctx that has to
4429  be used across all parallel_scan methods. Also, gets the number of
4430  threads that would be spawned for parallel scan.
4431  @param[out] scan_ctx The parallel scan context.
4432  @param[out] num_threads Number of threads used for the scan.
4433  @param[in] use_reserved_threads true if reserved threads are to be used
4434  if we exhaust the max cap of number of
4435  parallel read threads that can be
4436  spawned at a time
4437  @return error code
4438  @retval 0 on success
4439  */
4440  virtual int parallel_scan_init(void *&scan_ctx MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
4441  size_t *num_threads MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
4442  bool use_reserved_threads
4443  MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
4444  return 0;
4445  }
4446 
4447  /**
4448  This callback is called by each parallel load thread at the beginning of
4449  the parallel load for the adapter scan.
4450  @param cookie The cookie for this thread
4451  @param ncols Number of columns in each row
4452  @param row_len The size of a row in bytes
4453  @param col_offsets An array of size ncols, where each element represents
4454  the offset of a column in the row data. The memory of
4455  this array belongs to the caller and will be free-ed
4456  after the pload_end_cbk call.
4457  @param null_byte_offsets An array of size ncols, where each element
4458  represents the offset of a column in the row data. The
4459  memory of this array belongs to the caller and will be
4460  free-ed after the pload_end_cbk call.
4461  @param null_bitmasks An array of size ncols, where each element
4462  represents the bitmask required to get the null bit. The
4463  memory of this array belongs to the caller and will be
4464  free-ed after the pload_end_cbk call.
4465  */
4466  using Load_init_cbk = std::function<bool(
4467  void *cookie, ulong ncols, ulong row_len, const ulong *col_offsets,
4468  const ulong *null_byte_offsets, const ulong *null_bitmasks)>;
4469 
4470  /**
4471  This callback is called by each parallel load thread when processing
4472  of rows is required for the adapter scan.
4473  @param[in] cookie The cookie for this thread
4474  @param[in] nrows The nrows that are available
4475  @param[in] rowdata The mysql-in-memory row data buffer. This is a
4476  memory buffer for nrows records. The length of each record is fixed and
4477  communicated via Load_init_cbk
4478  @param[in] partition_id Partition id if it's a partitioned table, else
4479  std::numeric_limits<uint64_t>::max()
4480  @returns true if there is an error, false otherwise.
4481  */
4482  using Load_cbk = std::function<bool(void *cookie, uint nrows, void *rowdata,
4483  uint64_t partition_id)>;
4484 
4485  /**
4486  This callback is called by each parallel load thread when processing
4487  of rows has ended for the adapter scan.
4488  @param[in] cookie The cookie for this thread
4489  */
4490  using Load_end_cbk = std::function<void(void *cookie)>;
4491 
4492  /**
4493  Run the parallel read of data.
4494  @param[in] scan_ctx Scan context of the parallel read.
4495  @param[in,out] thread_ctxs Caller thread contexts.
4496  @param[in] init_fn Callback called by each parallel load
4497  thread at the beginning of the parallel load.
4498  @param[in] load_fn Callback called by each parallel load
4499  thread when processing of rows is required.
4500  @param[in] end_fn Callback called by each parallel load
4501  thread when processing of rows has ended.
4502  @return error code
4503  @retval 0 on success
4504  */
4505  virtual int parallel_scan(void *scan_ctx MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
4506  void **thread_ctxs MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
4507  Load_init_cbk init_fn MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
4508  Load_cbk load_fn MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
4509  Load_end_cbk end_fn MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
4510  return 0;
4511  }
4512 
4513  /**
4514  End of the parallel scan.
4515  @param[in] scan_ctx A scan context created by parallel_scan_init.
4516  */
4517  virtual void parallel_scan_end(void *scan_ctx MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
4518  return;
4519  }
4520 
4521  /**
4522  Submit a dd::Table object representing a core DD table having
4523  hardcoded data to be filled in by the DDSE. This function can be
4524  used for retrieving the hard coded SE private data for the
4525  mysql.dd_properties table, before creating or opening it, or for
4526  retrieving the hard coded SE private data for a core table,
4527  before creating or opening them.
4528 
4529  @param dd_table [in,out] A dd::Table object representing
4530  a core DD table.
4531  @param reset Reset counters.
4532 
4533  @retval true An error occurred.
4534  @retval false Success - no errors.
4535  */
4536 
4537  bool ha_get_se_private_data(dd::Table *dd_table, bool reset);
4538 
4539  void adjust_next_insert_id_after_explicit_value(ulonglong nr);
4540  int update_auto_increment();
4541  virtual void print_error(int error, myf errflag);
4542  virtual bool get_error_message(int error, String *buf);
4543  uint get_dup_key(int error);
4544  /**
4545  Retrieves the names of the table and the key for which there was a
4546  duplicate entry in the case of HA_ERR_FOREIGN_DUPLICATE_KEY.
4547
