4548  If any of the table or key name is not available this method will return
4549  false and will not change any of child_table_name or child_key_name.
4550 
4551  @param [out] child_table_name Table name
4552  @param [in] child_table_name_len Table name buffer size
4553  @param [out] child_key_name Key name
4554  @param [in] child_key_name_len Key name buffer size
4555 
4556  @retval true table and key names were available
4557  and were written into the corresponding
4558  out parameters.
4559  @retval false table and key names were not available,
4560  the out parameters were not touched.
4561  */
4562  virtual bool get_foreign_dup_key(char *child_table_name,
4563  uint child_table_name_len,
4564  char *child_key_name,
4565  uint child_key_name_len);
4566  /**
4567  Change the internal TABLE_SHARE pointer.
4568 
4569  @param table_arg TABLE object
4570  @param share New share to use
4571 
4572  @note Is used in error handling in ha_delete_table.
4573  */
4574 
4575  virtual void change_table_ptr(TABLE *table_arg, TABLE_SHARE *share) {
4576  table = table_arg;
4577  table_share = share;
4578  }
4579  const TABLE_SHARE *get_table_share() const { return table_share; }
4580 
4581  /* Estimates calculation */
4582 
4583  /**
4584  @deprecated This function is deprecated and will be removed in a future
4585  version. Use table_scan_cost() instead.
4586  */
4587 
4588  virtual double scan_time() {
4589  return ulonglong2double(stats.data_file_length) / IO_SIZE + 2;
4590  }
4591 
4592  /**
4593  The cost of reading a set of ranges from the table using an index
4594  to access it.
4595 
4596  @deprecated This function is deprecated and will be removed in a future
4597  version. Use read_cost() instead.
4598 
4599  @param index The index number.
4600  @param ranges The number of ranges to be read.
4601  @param rows Total number of rows to be read.
4602 
4603  This method can be used to calculate the total cost of scanning a table
4604  using an index by calling it using read_time(index, 1, table_size).
4605  */
4606 
4607  virtual double read_time(uint index MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)), uint ranges,
4608  ha_rows rows) {
4609  return rows2double(ranges + rows);
4610  }
4611 
4612  /**
4613  @deprecated This function is deprecated and will be removed in a future
4614  version. Use index_scan_cost() instead.
4615  */
4616 
4617  virtual double index_only_read_time(uint keynr, double records);
4618 
4619  /**
4620  Cost estimate for doing a complete table scan.
4621 
4622  @note For this version it is recommended that storage engines continue
4623  to override scan_time() instead of this function.
4624 
4625  @returns the estimated cost
4626  */
4627 
4628  virtual Cost_estimate table_scan_cost();
4629 
4630  /**
4631  Cost estimate for reading a number of ranges from an index.
4632 
4633  The cost estimate will only include the cost of reading data that
4634  is contained in the index. If the records need to be read, use
4635  read_cost() instead.
4636 
4637  @note The ranges parameter is currently ignored and is not taken
4638  into account in the cost estimate.
4639 
4640  @note For this version it is recommended that storage engines continue
4641  to override index_only_read_time() instead of this function.
4642 
4643  @param index the index number
4644  @param ranges the number of ranges to be read
4645  @param rows total number of rows to be read
4646 
4647  @returns the estimated cost
4648  */
4649 
4650  virtual Cost_estimate index_scan_cost(uint index, double ranges, double rows);
4651 
4652  /**
4653  Cost estimate for reading a set of ranges from the table using an index
4654  to access it.
4655 
4656  @note For this version it is recommended that storage engines continue
4657  to override read_time() instead of this function.
4658 
4659  @param index the index number
4660  @param ranges the number of ranges to be read
4661  @param rows total number of rows to be read
4662 
4663  @returns the estimated cost
4664  */
4665 
4666  virtual Cost_estimate read_cost(uint index, double ranges, double rows);
4667 
4668  /**
4669  Return an estimate on the amount of memory the storage engine will
4670  use for caching data in memory. If this is unknown or the storage
4671  engine does not cache data in memory -1 is returned.
4672  */
4673  virtual longlong get_memory_buffer_size() const { return -1; }
4674 
4675  /**
4676  Return an estimate of how much of the table that is currently stored
4677  in main memory.
4678 
4679  This estimate should be the fraction of the table that currently
4680  is available in a main memory buffer. The estimate should be in the
4681  range from 0.0 (nothing in memory) to 1.0 (entire table in memory).
4682 
4683  @return The fraction of the table in main memory buffer
4684  */
4685 
4686  double table_in_memory_estimate() const;
4687 
4688  /**
4689  Return an estimate of how much of the index that is currently stored
4690  in main memory.
4691 
4692  This estimate should be the fraction of the index that currently
4693  is available in a main memory buffer. The estimate should be in the
4694  range from 0.0 (nothing in memory) to 1.0 (entire index in memory).
4695 
4696  @param keyno the index to get an estimate for
4697 
4698  @return The fraction of the index in main memory buffer
4699  */
4700 
4701  double index_in_memory_estimate(uint keyno) const;
4702 
4703  /**
4704  Initialize sampling.
4705 
4706  @param[out] scan_ctx A scan context created by this method that has to be
4707  used in sample_next
4708  @param[in] sampling_percentage percentage of records that need to be
4709  sampled
4710  @param[in] sampling_seed random seed that the random generator will
4711  use
4712  @param[in] sampling_method sampling method to be used; currently only
4713  SYSTEM sampling is supported
4714 
4715  @return 0 for success, else one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4716  */
4717  int ha_sample_init(void *&scan_ctx, double sampling_percentage,
4718  int sampling_seed, enum_sampling_method sampling_method);
4719 
4720  /**
4721  Get the next record for sampling.
4722 
4723  @param[in] scan_ctx Scan context of the sampling
4724  @param[in] buf buffer to place the read record
4725 
4726  @return 0 for success, else one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4727  */
4728  int ha_sample_next(void *scan_ctx, uchar *buf);
4729 
4730  /**
4731  End sampling.
4732 
4733  @param[in] scan_ctx Scan context of the sampling
4734 
4735  @return 0 for success, else one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4736  */
4737  int ha_sample_end(void *scan_ctx);
4738 
4739  private:
4740  int check_collation_compatibility();
4741 
4742  /**
4743  Make a guestimate for how much of a table or index is in a memory
4744  buffer in the case where the storage engine has not provided any
4745  estimate for this.
4746 
4747  @param table_index_size size of the table or index
4748 
4749  @return The fraction of the table or index in main memory buffer
4750  */
4751 
4752  double estimate_in_memory_buffer(ulonglong table_index_size) const;
4753 
4754  public:
4755  virtual ha_rows multi_range_read_info_const(uint keyno, RANGE_SEQ_IF *seq,
4756  void *seq_init_param,
4757  uint n_ranges, uint *bufsz,
4758  uint *flags, Cost_estimate *cost);
4759  virtual ha_rows multi_range_read_info(uint keyno, uint n_ranges, uint keys,
4760  uint *bufsz, uint *flags,
4761  Cost_estimate *cost);
4762  virtual int multi_range_read_init(RANGE_SEQ_IF *seq, void *seq_init_param,
4763  uint n_ranges, uint mode,
4764  HANDLER_BUFFER *buf);
4765 
4766  int ha_multi_range_read_next(char **range_info);
4767 
4768  int ha_read_range_first(const key_range *start_key, const key_range *end_key,
4769  bool eq_range, bool sorted);
4770  int ha_read_range_next();
4771 
4772  bool has_transactions() {
4773  return (ha_table_flags() & HA_NO_TRANSACTIONS) == 0;
4774  }
4775  virtual uint extra_rec_buf_length() const { return 0; }
4776 
4777  /**
4778  @brief Determine whether an error can be ignored or not.
4779 
4780  @details This method is used to analyze the error to see whether the
4781  error is ignorable or not. Such errors will be reported as warnings
4782  instead of errors for IGNORE statements. This means that the statement
4783  will not abort, but instead continue to the next row.
4784 
4785  HA_ERR_FOUND_DUP_UNIQUE is a special case in MyISAM that means the
4786  same thing as HA_ERR_FOUND_DUP_KEY, but can in some cases lead to
4787  a slightly different error message.
4788 
4789  @param error error code received from the handler interface (HA_ERR_...)
4790 
4791  @return whether the error is ignorablel or not
4792  @retval true the error is ignorable
4793  @retval false the error is not ignorable
4794  */
4795 
4796  virtual bool is_ignorable_error(int error);
4797 
4798  /**
4799  @brief Determine whether an error is fatal or not.
4800 
4801  @details This method is used to analyze the error to see whether the
4802  error is fatal or not. A fatal error is an error that will not be
4803  possible to handle with SP handlers and will not be subject to
4804  retry attempts on the slave.
4805 
4806  @param error error code received from the handler interface (HA_ERR_...)
4807 
4808  @return whether the error is fatal or not
4809  @retval true the error is fatal
4810  @retval false the error is not fatal
4811  */
4812 
4813  virtual bool is_fatal_error(int error);
4814 
4815  protected:
4816  virtual int multi_range_read_next(char **range_info);
4817 
4818  /**
4819  Number of rows in table. If HA_COUNT_ROWS_INSTANT is set, count is
4820  available instantly. Else do a table scan.
4821 
4822  @param num_rows [out] num_rows number of rows in table.
4823 
4824  @retval 0 for OK, one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4825  */
4826  virtual int records(ha_rows *num_rows);
4827 
4828  /**
4829  Number of rows in table counted using the secondary index chosen by
4830  optimizer. See comments in optimize_aggregated_query() .
4831 
4832  @param num_rows [out] Number of rows in table.
4833  @param index Index chosen by optimizer for counting.
4834 
4835  @retval 0 for OK, one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4836  */
4837  virtual int records_from_index(ha_rows *num_rows, uint index);
4838 
4839  private:
4840  /**
4841  Function will handle the error code from call to records() and
4842  records_from_index().
4843 
4844  @param error return code from records() and records_from_index().
4845  @param num_rows Check if it contains HA_POS_ERROR in case error < 0.
4846 
4847  @retval 0 for OK, one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4848  */
4849  int handle_records_error(int error, ha_rows *num_rows);
4850 
4851  public:
4852  /**
4853  Wrapper function to call records() in storage engine.
4854 
4855  @param num_rows [out] Number of rows in table.
4856 
4857  @retval 0 for OK, one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4858  */
4859  int ha_records(ha_rows *num_rows) {
4860  return handle_records_error(records(num_rows), num_rows);
4861  }
4862 
4863  /**
4864  Wrapper function to call records_from_index() in storage engine.
4865 
4866  @param num_rows [out] Number of rows in table.
4867  @param index Index chosen by optimizer for counting.
4868 
4869  @retval 0 for OK, one of the HA_xxx values in case of error.
4870  */
4871  int ha_records(ha_rows *num_rows, uint index) {
4872  return handle_records_error(records_from_index(num_rows, index), num_rows);
4873  }
4874 
4875  /**
4876  Return upper bound of current number of records in the table
4877  (max. of how many records one will retrieve when doing a full table scan)
4878  If upper bound is not known, HA_POS_ERROR should be returned as a max
4879  possible upper bound.
4880  */
4881  virtual ha_rows estimate_rows_upper_bound() {
4882  return stats.records + EXTRA_RECORDS;
4883  }
4884 
4885  /**
4886  Get real row type for the table created based on one specified by user,
4887  CREATE TABLE options and SE capabilities.
4888  */
4889  virtual enum row_type get_real_row_type(
4890  const HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info) const {
4891  return (create_info->table_options & HA_OPTION_COMPRESS_RECORD)
4892  ? ROW_TYPE_COMPRESSED
4893  : ((create_info->table_options & HA_OPTION_PACK_RECORD)
4894  ? ROW_TYPE_DYNAMIC
4895  : ROW_TYPE_FIXED);
4896  }
4897 
4898  /**
4899  Get default key algorithm for SE. It is used when user has not provided
4900  algorithm explicitly or when algorithm specified is not supported by SE.
4901  */
4902  virtual enum ha_key_alg get_default_index_algorithm() const {
4903  return HA_KEY_ALG_SE_SPECIFIC;
4904  }
4905 
4906  /**
4907  Check if SE supports specific key algorithm.
4908 
4909  @note This method is never used for FULLTEXT or SPATIAL keys.
4910  We rely on handler::ha_table_flags() to check if such keys
4911  are supported.
4912  */
4913  virtual bool is_index_algorithm_supported(enum ha_key_alg key_alg) const {
4914  return key_alg == HA_KEY_ALG_SE_SPECIFIC;
4915  }
4916 
4917  /**
4918  Signal that the table->read_set and table->write_set table maps changed
4919  The handler is allowed to set additional bits in the above map in this
4920  call. Normally the handler should ignore all calls until we have done
4921  a ha_rnd_init() or ha_index_init(), write_row(), update_row or delete_row()
4922  as there may be several calls to this routine.
4923  */
4924  virtual void column_bitmaps_signal();
4925  uint get_index(void) const { return active_index; }
4926 
4927  /**
4928  @retval false Bulk update used by handler
4929  @retval true Bulk update not used, normal operation used
4930  */
4931  virtual bool start_bulk_update() { return true; }
4932  /**
4933  @retval false Bulk delete used by handler
4934  @retval true Bulk delete not used, normal operation used
4935  */
4936  virtual bool start_bulk_delete() { return true; }
4937  /**
4938  After this call all outstanding updates must be performed. The number
4939  of duplicate key errors are reported in the duplicate key parameter.
4940  It is allowed to continue to the batched update after this call, the
4941  handler has to wait until end_bulk_update with changing state.
4942 
4943  @param dup_key_found Number of duplicate keys found
4944 
4945  @retval 0 Success
4946  @retval >0 Error code
4947  */
4948  virtual int exec_bulk_update(uint *dup_key_found MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
4949  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
4950  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
4951  }
4952  /**
4953  Perform any needed clean-up, no outstanding updates are there at the
4954  moment.
4955  */
4956  virtual void end_bulk_update() { return; }
4957  /**
4958  Execute all outstanding deletes and close down the bulk delete.
4959 
4960  @retval 0 Success
4961  @retval >0 Error code
4962  */
4963  virtual int end_bulk_delete() {
4964  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
4965  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
4966  }
4967 
4968  protected:
4969  /**
4970  @brief
4971  Positions an index cursor to the index specified in the handle
4972  ('active_index'). Fetches the row if available. If the key value is null,
4973  begin at the first key of the index.
4974  @returns 0 if success (found a record); non-zero if no record.
4975  */
4976  virtual int index_read_map(uchar *buf, const uchar *key,
4977  key_part_map keypart_map,
4978  enum ha_rkey_function find_flag) {
4979  uint key_len = calculate_key_len(table, active_index, keypart_map);
4980  return index_read(buf, key, key_len, find_flag);
4981  }
4982  /**
4983  Positions an index cursor to the index specified in argument. Fetches
4984  the row if available. If the key value is null, begin at the first key of
4985  the index.
4986  @sa index_read_map()
4987  */
4988  virtual int index_read_idx_map(uchar *buf, uint index, const uchar *key,
4989  key_part_map keypart_map,
4990  enum ha_rkey_function find_flag);
4991 
4992  /*
4993  These methods are used to jump to next or previous entry in the index
4994  scan. There are also methods to jump to first and last entry.
4995  */
4996  /// @see index_read_map().
4997  virtual int index_next(uchar *) { return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND; }
4998 
4999  /// @see index_read_map().
5000  virtual int index_prev(uchar *) { return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND; }
5001 
5002  /// @see index_read_map().
5003  virtual int index_first(uchar *) { return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND; }
5004 
5005  /// @see index_read_map().
5006  virtual int index_last(uchar *) { return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND; }
5007 
5008  /// @see index_read_map().
5009  virtual int index_next_same(uchar *buf, const uchar *key, uint keylen);
5010  /**
5011  The following functions works like index_read, but it find the last
5012  row with the current key value or prefix.
5013  @see index_read_map().
5014  */
5015  virtual int index_read_last_map(uchar *buf, const uchar *key,
5016  key_part_map keypart_map) {
5017  uint key_len = calculate_key_len(table, active_index, keypart_map);
5018  return index_read_last(buf, key, key_len);
5019  }
5020 
5021  virtual int read_range_first(const key_range *start_key,
5022  const key_range *end_key, bool eq_range,
5023  bool sorted);
5024  virtual int read_range_next();
5025 
5026  public:
5027  /**
5028  Set the end position for a range scan. This is used for checking
5029  for when to end the range scan and by the ICP code to determine
5030  that the next record is within the current range.
5031 
5032  @param range The end value for the range scan
5033  @param direction Direction of the range scan
5034  */
5035  void set_end_range(const key_range *range,
5036  enum_range_scan_direction direction);
5037  int compare_key(key_range *range);
5038  int compare_key_icp(const key_range *range) const;
5039  int compare_key_in_buffer(const uchar *buf) const;
5040  virtual int ft_init() { return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND; }
5041  void ft_end() { ft_handler = nullptr; }
5042  virtual FT_INFO *ft_init_ext(uint flags MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5043  uint inx MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5044  String *key MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5045  return nullptr;
5046  }
5047  virtual FT_INFO *ft_init_ext_with_hints(uint inx, String *key,
5048  Ft_hints *hints) {
5049  return ft_init_ext(hints->get_flags(), inx, key);
5050  }
5051  int ha_ft_read(uchar *buf);
5052  int ha_read_first_row(uchar *buf, uint primary_key);
5053 
5054  protected:
5055  /// @see index_read_map().
5056  virtual int rnd_next(uchar *buf) = 0;
5057  /// @see index_read_map().
5058  virtual int rnd_pos(uchar *buf, uchar *pos) = 0;
5059 
5060  virtual int ft_read(uchar *) { return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND; }
5061 
5062  public:
5063  /**
5064  This function only works for handlers having
5065  HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION set.
5066  It will return the row with the PK given in the record argument.
5067  */
5068  virtual int rnd_pos_by_record(uchar *record) {
5069  int error;
5070  DBUG_ASSERT(table_flags() & HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION);
5071 
5072  error = ha_rnd_init(false);
5073  if (error != 0) return error;
5074 
5075  position(record);
5076  error = ha_rnd_pos(record, ref);
5077 
5078  ha_rnd_end();
5079  return error;
5080  }
5081 
5082  /**
5083  Find number of records in a range.
5084 
5085  Given a starting key, and an ending key estimate the number of rows that
5086  will exist between the two. max_key may be empty which in case determine
5087  if start_key matches any rows. Used by optimizer to calculate cost of
5088  using a particular index.
5089 
5090  @param inx Index number
5091  @param min_key Start of range
5092  @param max_key End of range
5093 
5094  @return Number of rows in range.
5095  */
5096 
5097  virtual ha_rows records_in_range(uint inx MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5098  key_range *min_key MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5099  key_range *max_key MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5100  return (ha_rows)10;
5101  }
5102  /*
5103  If HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION is set, then it sets ref
5104  (reference to the row, aka position, with the primary key given in
5105  the record).
5106  Otherwise it set ref to the current row.
5107  */
5108  virtual void position(const uchar *record) = 0;
5109 
5110  /**
5111  General method to gather info from handler
5112 
5113  ::info() is used to return information to the optimizer.
5114  SHOW also makes use of this data Another note, if your handler
5115  doesn't proved exact record count, you will probably want to
5116  have the following in your code:
5117  if (records < 2)
5118  records = 2;
5119  The reason is that the server will optimize for cases of only a single
5120  record. If in a table scan you don't know the number of records
5121  it will probably be better to set records to two so you can return
5122  as many records as you need.
5123 
5124  Along with records a few more variables you may wish to set are:
5125  records
5126  deleted
5127  data_file_length
5128  index_file_length
5129  delete_length
5130  check_time
5131  Take a look at the public variables in handler.h for more information.
5132  See also my_base.h for a full description.
5133 
5134  @param flag Specifies what info is requested
5135  */
5136 
5137  virtual int info(uint flag) = 0;
5138  virtual uint32 calculate_key_hash_value(
5139  Field **field_array MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5140  DBUG_ASSERT(0);
5141  return 0;
5142  }
5143  /**
5144  Request storage engine to do an extra operation: enable,disable or run some
5145  functionality.
5146 
5147  @param operation the operation to perform
5148 
5149  @returns
5150  0 on success
5151  error otherwise
5152  */
5153  int ha_extra(enum ha_extra_function operation);
5154 
5155  private:
5156  /**
5157  Storage engine specific implementation of ha_extra()
5158 
5159  @param operation the operation to perform
5160 
5161  @returns
5162  0 on success
5163  error otherwise
5164  */
5165  virtual int extra(enum ha_extra_function operation MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5166  return 0;
5167  }
5168 
5169  public:
5170  virtual int extra_opt(enum ha_extra_function operation,
5171  ulong cache_size MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5172  return extra(operation);
5173  }
5174 
5175  /**
5176  Let storage engine inspect the optimized 'plan' and pick whatever
5177  it like for being pushed down to the engine. (Join, conditions, ..)
5178 
5179  The handler implementation should keep track of what it 'pushed',
5180  such that later calls to the handlers access methods should
5181  activate the pushed (part of) the execution plan on the storage
5182  engines.
5183 
5184  @param table
5185  Abstract Query Plan 'table' object for the table
5186  being pushed to
5187 
5188  @returns
5189  0 on success
5190  error otherwise
5191  */
5192  virtual int engine_push(AQP::Table_access *table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5193  return 0;
5194  }
5195 
5196  /**
5197  Start read (before write) removal on the current table.
5198  @see HA_READ_BEFORE_WRITE_REMOVAL
5199  */
5200  virtual bool start_read_removal(void) {
5201  DBUG_ASSERT(0);
5202  return false;
5203  }
5204 
5205  /**
5206  End read (before write) removal and return the number of rows
5207  really written
5208  @see HA_READ_BEFORE_WRITE_REMOVAL
5209  */
5210  virtual ha_rows end_read_removal(void) {
5211  DBUG_ASSERT(0);
5212  return (ha_rows)0;
5213  }
5214 
5215  /**
5216  Normally, when running UPDATE or DELETE queries, we need to wait for other
5217  transactions to release their locks on a given row before we can read it and
5218  potentially update it. However, in READ UNCOMMITTED and READ COMMITTED, we
5219  can ignore these locks if we don't intend to modify the row (e.g., because
5220  it failed a WHERE). This is signaled through enabling “semi-consistent
5221  read”, by calling try_semi_consistent_read(true) (and then setting it back
5222  to false after finishing the query).
5223 
5224  If semi-consistent read is enabled, and we are in READ UNCOMMITTED or READ
5225  COMMITTED, the storage engine is permitted to return rows that are locked
5226  and thus un-updatable. If the optimizer doesn't want the row, e.g., because
5227  it got filtered out, it can call unlock_row() as usual. However, if it
5228  intends to update the row, it needs to call was_semi_consistent_read()
5229  before doing so. If was_semi_consistent_read() returns false, the row was
5230  never locked to begin with and can be updated as usual. However, if it
5231  returns 1, it was read optimistically, must be discarded (ie., do not try to
5232  update the row) and must be re-read with locking enabled. The next read call
5233  after was_semi_consistent_read() will automatically re-read the same row,
5234  this time with locking enabled.
5235 
5236  Thus, typical use in an UPDATE scenario would look like this:
5237 
5238  file->try_semi_consistent_read(true);
5239  file->ha_rnd_init(true);
5240  while (file->ha_rnd_next(table->record[0]) == 0) {
5241  if (row is filtered...) {
5242  file->unlock_row();
5243  continue;
5244  }
5245  if (file->was_semi_consistent_read()) {
5246  // Discard the row; next ha_rnd_next() will read it again with
5247  // locking.
5248  continue;
5249  }
5250  // Process row here.
5251  }
5252  file->ha_rnd_end();
5253  file->try_semi_consistent_read(false);
5254 
5255  If the transaction isolation level is REPEATABLE READ or SERIALIZABLE,
5256  enabling this flag has no effect.
5257  */
5258  virtual bool was_semi_consistent_read() { return false; }
5259  /**
5260  Tell the engine whether it should avoid unnecessary lock waits.
5261  If yes, in an UPDATE or DELETE, if the row under the cursor was locked
5262  by another transaction, the engine may try an optimistic read of
5263  the last committed row value under the cursor.
5264  */
5265  virtual void try_semi_consistent_read(bool) {}
5266 
5267  /**
5268  Unlock last accessed row.
5269 
5270  Record currently processed was not in the result set of the statement
5271  and is thus unlocked. Used for UPDATE and DELETE queries.
5272  */
5273 
5274  virtual void unlock_row() {}
5275 
5276  /**
5277  Start a statement when table is locked
5278 
5279  This method is called instead of external lock when the table is locked
5280  before the statement is executed.
5281 
5282  @param thd Thread object.
5283  @param lock_type Type of external lock.
5284 
5285  @retval >0 Error code.
5286  @retval 0 Success.
5287  */
5288 
5289  virtual int start_stmt(THD *thd MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5290  thr_lock_type lock_type MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5291  return 0;
5292  }
5293  virtual void get_auto_increment(ulonglong offset, ulonglong increment,
5294  ulonglong nb_desired_values,
5295  ulonglong *first_value,
5296  ulonglong *nb_reserved_values);
5297  void set_next_insert_id(ulonglong id) {
5298  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("auto_increment: next value %lu", (ulong)id));
5299  next_insert_id = id;
5300  }
5301  void restore_auto_increment(ulonglong prev_insert_id) {
5302  /*
5303  Insertion of a row failed, re-use the lastly generated auto_increment
5304  id, for the next row. This is achieved by resetting next_insert_id to
5305  what it was before the failed insertion (that old value is provided by
5306  the caller). If that value was 0, it was the first row of the INSERT;
5307  then if insert_id_for_cur_row contains 0 it means no id was generated
5308  for this first row, so no id was generated since the INSERT started, so
5309  we should set next_insert_id to 0; if insert_id_for_cur_row is not 0, it
5310  is the generated id of the first and failed row, so we use it.
5311  */
5312  next_insert_id =
5313  (prev_insert_id > 0) ? prev_insert_id : insert_id_for_cur_row;
5314  }
5315 
5316  /**
5317  Update create info as part of ALTER TABLE.
5318 
5319  Forward this handler call to the storage engine foreach
5320  partition handler. The data_file_name for each partition may
5321  need to be reset if the tablespace was moved. Use a dummy
5322  HA_CREATE_INFO structure and transfer necessary data.
5323 
5324  @param create_info Create info from ALTER TABLE.
5325  */
5326 
5327  virtual void update_create_info(
5328  HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {}
5329  virtual int assign_to_keycache(THD *, HA_CHECK_OPT *) {
5330  return HA_ADMIN_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
5331  }
5332  virtual int preload_keys(THD *, HA_CHECK_OPT *) {
5333  return HA_ADMIN_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
5334  }
5335  /* end of the list of admin commands */
5336 
5337  /**
5338  Check if indexes are disabled.
5339 
5340  @retval 0 Indexes are enabled.
5341  @retval != 0 Indexes are disabled.
5342  */
5343 
5344  virtual int indexes_are_disabled(void) { return 0; }
5345  virtual void append_create_info(String *packet MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {}
5346  virtual void init_table_handle_for_HANDLER() {
5347  return;
5348  } /* prepare InnoDB for HANDLER */
5349  /** The following can be called without an open handler */
5350  virtual const char *table_type() const = 0;
5351 
5352  virtual ulong index_flags(uint idx, uint part, bool all_parts) const = 0;
5353 
5354  uint max_record_length() const {
5355  return std::min(HA_MAX_REC_LENGTH, max_supported_record_length());
5356  }
5357  uint max_keys() const {
5358  return std::min<uint>(MAX_KEY, max_supported_keys());
5359  }
5360  uint max_key_parts() const {
5361  return std::min(MAX_REF_PARTS, max_supported_key_parts());
5362  }
5363  uint max_key_length() const {
5364  return std::min(MAX_KEY_LENGTH, max_supported_key_length());
5365  }
5366  uint max_key_part_length(HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info) const {
5367  return std::min(MAX_KEY_LENGTH, max_supported_key_part_length(create_info));
5368  }
5369 
5370  virtual uint max_supported_record_length() const { return HA_MAX_REC_LENGTH; }
5371  virtual uint max_supported_keys() const { return 0; }
5372  virtual uint max_supported_key_parts() const { return MAX_REF_PARTS; }
5373  virtual uint max_supported_key_length() const { return MAX_KEY_LENGTH; }
5374  virtual uint max_supported_key_part_length(
5375  HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) const {
5376  return 255;
5377  }
5378  virtual uint min_record_length(uint options MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) const {
5379  return 1;
5380  }
5381 
5382  virtual bool low_byte_first() const { return true; }
5383  virtual ha_checksum checksum() const { return 0; }
5384 
5385  /**
5386  Check if the table is crashed.
5387 
5388  @retval true Crashed
5389  @retval false Not crashed
5390  */
5391 
5392  virtual bool is_crashed() const { return false; }
5393 
5394  /**
5395  Check if the table can be automatically repaired.
5396 
5397  @retval true Can be auto repaired
5398  @retval false Cannot be auto repaired
5399  */
5400 
5401  virtual bool auto_repair() const { return false; }
5402 
5403  /**
5404  Get number of lock objects returned in store_lock.
5405 
5406  Returns the number of store locks needed in call to store lock.
5407  We return number of partitions we will lock multiplied with number of
5408  locks needed by each partition. Assists the above functions in allocating
5409  sufficient space for lock structures.
5410 
5411  @returns Number of locks returned in call to store_lock.
5412 
5413  @note lock_count() can return > 1 if the table is MERGE or partitioned.
5414  */
5415 
5416  virtual uint lock_count(void) const { return 1; }
5417 
5418  /**
5419  Is not invoked for non-transactional temporary tables.
5420 
5421  @note store_lock() can return more than one lock if the table is MERGE
5422  or partitioned.
5423 
5424  @note that one can NOT rely on table->in_use in store_lock(). It may
5425  refer to a different thread if called from mysql_lock_abort_for_thread().
5426 
5427  @note If the table is MERGE, store_lock() can return less locks
5428  than lock_count() claimed. This can happen when the MERGE children
5429  are not attached when this is called from another thread.
5430 
5431  The idea with handler::store_lock() is the following:
5432 
5433  The statement decided which locks we should need for the table
5434  for updates/deletes/inserts we get WRITE locks, for SELECT... we get
5435  read locks.
5436 
5437  Before adding the lock into the table lock handler (see thr_lock.c)
5438  mysqld calls store lock with the requested locks. Store lock can now
5439  modify a write lock to a read lock (or some other lock), ignore the
5440  lock (if we don't want to use MySQL table locks at all) or add locks
5441  for many tables (like we do when we are using a MERGE handler).
5442 
5443  In some exceptional cases MySQL may send a request for a TL_IGNORE;
5444  This means that we are requesting the same lock as last time and this
5445  should also be ignored.
5446 
5447  Called from lock.cc by get_lock_data().
5448  */
5449  virtual THR_LOCK_DATA **store_lock(THD *thd, THR_LOCK_DATA **to,
5450  enum thr_lock_type lock_type) = 0;
5451 
5452  /**
5453  Check if the primary key is clustered or not.
5454 
5455  @retval true Primary key (if there is one) is a clustered
5456  key covering all fields
5457  @retval false otherwise
5458  */
5459 
5460  virtual bool primary_key_is_clustered() const { return false; }
5461 
5462  /**
5463  Compare two positions.
5464 
5465  @param ref1 First position.
5466  @param ref2 Second position.
5467 
5468  @retval <0 ref1 < ref2.
5469  @retval 0 Equal.
5470  @retval >0 ref1 > ref2.
5471  */
5472 
5473  virtual int cmp_ref(const uchar *ref1, const uchar *ref2) const {
5474  return memcmp(ref1, ref2, ref_length);
5475  }
5476 
5477  /*
5478  Condition pushdown to storage engines
5479  */
5480 
5481  /**
5482  Push condition down to the table handler.
5483 
5484  @param cond Condition to be pushed. The condition tree
5485  must not be modified by the caller.
5486  @param other_tbls_ok Are other tables than than 'this' allowed to
5487  be referred by the condition terms being pushed.
5488 
5489  @return
5490  The 'remainder' condition that caller must use to filter out records.
5491  NULL means the handler will not return rows that do not match the
5492  passed condition.
5493 
5494  @note
5495  handler->ha_reset() call discard any pushed conditions.
5496  Calls to rnd_init/rnd_end, index_init/index_end etc do not affect the
5497  pushed conditions.
5498  */
5499  virtual const Item *cond_push(const Item *cond,
5500  bool other_tbls_ok MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5501  DBUG_ASSERT(pushed_cond == nullptr);
5502  return cond;
5503  }
5504 
5505  /**
5506  Push down an index condition to the handler.
5507 
5508  The server will use this method to push down a condition it wants
5509  the handler to evaluate when retrieving records using a specified
5510  index. The pushed index condition will only refer to fields from
5511  this handler that is contained in the index (but it may also refer
5512  to fields in other handlers). Before the handler evaluates the
5513  condition it must read the content of the index entry into the
5514  record buffer.
5515 
5516  The handler is free to decide if and how much of the condition it
5517  will take responsibility for evaluating. Based on this evaluation
5518  it should return the part of the condition it will not evaluate.
5519  If it decides to evaluate the entire condition it should return
5520  NULL. If it decides not to evaluate any part of the condition it
5521  should return a pointer to the same condition as given as argument.
5522 
5523  @param keyno the index number to evaluate the condition on
5524  @param idx_cond the condition to be evaluated by the handler
5525 
5526  @return The part of the pushed condition that the handler decides
5527  not to evaluate
5528  */
5529 
5530  virtual Item *idx_cond_push(uint keyno MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5531  Item *idx_cond) {
5532  return idx_cond;
5533  }
5534 
5535  /** Reset information about pushed index conditions */
5536  virtual void cancel_pushed_idx_cond() {
5537  pushed_idx_cond = nullptr;
5538  pushed_idx_cond_keyno = MAX_KEY;
5539  in_range_check_pushed_down = false;
5540  }
5541 
5542  /**
5543  Reports number of tables included in pushed join which this
5544  handler instance is part of. ==0 -> Not pushed
5545  */
5546  virtual uint number_of_pushed_joins() const { return 0; }
5547 
5548  /**
5549  If this handler instance is part of a pushed join sequence
5550  returned TABLE instance being root of the pushed query?
5551  */
5552  virtual const TABLE *member_of_pushed_join() const { return nullptr; }
5553 
5554  /**
5555  If this handler instance is a child in a pushed join sequence
5556  returned TABLE instance being my parent?
5557  */
5558  virtual const TABLE *parent_of_pushed_join() const { return nullptr; }
5559 
5560  /// @returns a map of the tables involved in this pushed join, or 0 if not
5561  /// part of a pushed join.
5562  virtual table_map tables_in_pushed_join() const { return 0; }
5563 
5564  int ha_index_read_pushed(uchar *buf, const uchar *key,
5565  key_part_map keypart_map);
5566 
5567  int ha_index_next_pushed(uchar *buf);
5568 
5569  protected:
5570  virtual int index_read_pushed(uchar *, const uchar *, key_part_map) {
5571  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
5572  }
5573 
5574  virtual int index_next_pushed(uchar *) { return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND; }
5575 
5576  public:
5577  /**
5578  Part of old, deprecated in-place ALTER API.
5579  */
5580  virtual bool check_if_incompatible_data(
5581  HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5582  uint table_changes MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5583  return COMPATIBLE_DATA_NO;
5584  }
5585 
5586  /* On-line/in-place/instant ALTER TABLE interface. */
5587 
5588  /*
5589  Here is an outline of on-line/in-place ALTER TABLE execution through
5590  this interface.
5591 
5592  Phase 1 : Initialization
5593  ========================
5594  During this phase we determine which algorithm should be used
5595  for execution of ALTER TABLE and what level concurrency it will
5596  require.
5597 
5598  *) This phase starts by opening the table and preparing description
5599  of the new version of the table.
5600  *) Then we check if it is impossible even in theory to carry out
5601  this ALTER TABLE using the in-place/instant algorithm. For example,
5602  because we need to change storage engine or the user has explicitly
5603  requested usage of the "copy" algorithm.
5604  *) If in-place/instant ALTER TABLE is theoretically possible, we continue
5605  by compiling differences between old and new versions of the table
5606  in the form of HA_ALTER_FLAGS bitmap. We also build a few
5607  auxiliary structures describing requested changes and store
5608  all these data in the Alter_inplace_info object.
5609  *) Then the handler::check_if_supported_inplace_alter() method is called
5610  in order to find if the storage engine can carry out changes requested
5611  by this ALTER TABLE using the in-place or instant algorithm.
5612  To determine this, the engine can rely on data in HA_ALTER_FLAGS/
5613  Alter_inplace_info passed to it as well as on its own checks.
5614  If the in-place algorithm can be used for this ALTER TABLE, the level
5615  of required concurrency for its execution is also returned.
5616  If any errors occur during the handler call, ALTER TABLE is aborted
5617  and no further handler functions are called.
5618  Note that in cases when there is difference between in-place and
5619  instant algorithm and user explicitly asked for usage of in-place
5620  algorithm storage engine MUST return one of values corresponding
5621  to in-place algorithm and not HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT from this
5622  method.
5623  *) Locking requirements of the in-place algorithm are compared to any
5624  concurrency requirements specified by user. If there is a conflict
5625  between them, we either switch to the copy algorithm or emit an error.
5626 
5627  Phase 2 : Execution
5628  ===================
5629 
5630  In this phase the operations are executed.
5631 
5632  *) As the first step, we acquire a lock corresponding to the concurrency
5633  level which was returned by handler::check_if_supported_inplace_alter()
5634  and requested by the user. This lock is held for most of the
5635  duration of in-place ALTER (if HA_ALTER_INPLACE_SHARED_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE
5636  or HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE were returned we acquire an
5637  exclusive lock for duration of the next step only).
5638  For HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT we keep shared upgradable metadata lock
5639  which was acquired at table open time.
5640  *) After that we call handler::ha_prepare_inplace_alter_table() to give the
5641  storage engine a chance to update its internal structures with a higher
5642  lock level than the one that will be used for the main step of algorithm.
5643  After that we downgrade the lock if it is necessary.
5644  This step should be no-op for instant algorithm.
5645  *) After that, the main step of this phase and algorithm is executed.
5646  We call the handler::ha_inplace_alter_table() method, which carries out
5647  the changes requested by ALTER TABLE but does not makes them visible to
5648  other connections yet.
5649  This step should be no-op for instant algorithm as well.
5650  *) We ensure that no other connection uses the table by upgrading our
5651  lock on it to exclusive.
5652  *) a) If the previous step succeeds,
5653  handler::ha_commit_inplace_alter_table() is called to allow the storage
5654  engine to do any final updates to its structures, to make all earlier
5655  changes durable and visible to other connections.
5656  For instant algorithm this is the step during which SE changes are done.
5657  Engines that support atomic DDL only prepare for the commit during this
5658  step but do not finalize it. Real commit happens later when the whole
5659  statement is committed. Also in some situations statement might be rolled
5660  back after call to commit_inplace_alter_table() for such storage engines.
5661  In the latter special case SE might require call to
5662  handlerton::dict_cache_reset() in order to invalidate its internal table
5663  definition cache after rollback.
5664  b) If we have failed to upgrade lock or any errors have occurred during
5665  the handler functions calls (including commit), we call
5666  handler::ha_commit_inplace_alter_table() to rollback all changes which
5667  were done during previous steps.
5668 
5669  All the above calls to SE are provided with dd::Table objects describing old
5670  and new version of table being altered. Engines which support atomic DDL are
5671  allowed to adjust object corresponding to the new version. During phase 3
5672  these changes are saved to the data-dictionary.
5673 
5674 
5675  Phase 3 : Final
5676  ===============
5677 
5678  In this phase we:
5679 
5680  a) For engines which don't support atomic DDL:
5681 
5682  *) Update the SQL-layer data-dictionary by replacing description of old
5683  version of the table with its new version. This change is immediately
5684  committed.
5685  *) Inform the storage engine about this change by calling the
5686  handler::ha_notify_table_changed() method.
5687  *) Process the RENAME clause by calling handler::ha_rename_table() and
5688  updating the data-dictionary accordingly. Again this change is
5689  immediately committed.
5690  *) Destroy the Alter_inplace_info and handler_ctx objects.
5691 
5692  b) For engines which support atomic DDL:
5693 
5694  *) Update the SQL-layer data-dictionary by replacing description of old
5695  version of the table with its new version.
5696  *) Process the RENAME clause by calling handler::ha_rename_table() and
5697  updating the data-dictionary accordingly.
5698  *) Commit the statement/transaction.
5699  *) Finalize atomic DDL operation by calling handlerton::post_ddl() hook
5700  for the storage engine.
5701  *) Additionally inform the storage engine about completion of ALTER TABLE
5702  for the table by calling the handler::ha_notify_table_changed()
5703  method.
5704  *) Destroy the Alter_inplace_info and handler_ctx objects.
5705  */
5706 
5707  /**
5708  Check if a storage engine supports a particular alter table in-place
5709 
5710  @param altered_table TABLE object for new version of table.
5711  @param ha_alter_info Structure describing changes to be done
5712  by ALTER TABLE and holding data used
5713  during in-place alter.
5714 
5715  @retval HA_ALTER_ERROR Unexpected error.
5716  @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NOT_SUPPORTED Not supported, must use copy.
5717  @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_EXCLUSIVE_LOCK Supported, but requires X lock.
5718  @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_SHARED_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE
5719  Supported, but requires SNW lock
5720  during main phase. Prepare phase
5721  requires X lock.
5722  @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_SHARED_LOCK Supported, but requires SNW lock.
5723  @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE
5724  Supported, concurrent
5725  reads/writes allowed. However, prepare phase requires X lock.
5726  @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK Supported, concurrent
5727  reads/writes allowed.
5728  @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT Instant algorithm is supported.
5729  Prepare and main phases are
5730  no-op. Changes happen during
5731  commit phase and it should be
5732  "instant". We keep SU lock,
5733  allowing concurrent reads and
5734  writes during no-op phases and
5735  upgrade it to X lock before
5736  commit phase.
5737 
5738  @note The default implementation uses the old in-place ALTER API
5739  to determine if the storage engine supports in-place ALTER or not.
5740 
5741  @note In cases when there is difference between in-place and instant
5742  algorithm and explicit ALGORITHM=INPLACE clause was provided SE MUST
5743  return one of values corresponding to in-place algorithm and not
5744  HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT from this method.
5745 
5746  @note Called without holding thr_lock.c lock.
5747  */
5748  virtual enum_alter_inplace_result check_if_supported_inplace_alter(
5749  TABLE *altered_table, Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info);
5750 
5751  /**
5752  Public functions wrapping the actual handler call.
5753  @see prepare_inplace_alter_table()
5754  */
5755  bool ha_prepare_inplace_alter_table(TABLE *altered_table,
5756  Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info,
5757  const dd::Table *old_table_def,
5758  dd::Table *new_table_def);
5759 
5760  /**
5761  Public function wrapping the actual handler call.
5762  @see inplace_alter_table()
5763  */
5764  bool ha_inplace_alter_table(TABLE *altered_table,
5765  Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info,
5766  const dd::Table *old_table_def,
5767  dd::Table *new_table_def) {
5768  return inplace_alter_table(altered_table, ha_alter_info, old_table_def,
5769  new_table_def);
5770  }
5771 
5772  /**
5773  Public function wrapping the actual handler call.
5774  Allows us to enforce asserts regardless of handler implementation.
5775  @see commit_inplace_alter_table()
5776  */
5777  bool ha_commit_inplace_alter_table(TABLE *altered_table,
5778  Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info,
5779  bool commit,
5780  const dd::Table *old_table_def,
5781  dd::Table *new_table_def);
5782 
5783  /**
5784  Public function wrapping the actual handler call.
5785 
5786  @see notify_table_changed()
5787  */
5788  void ha_notify_table_changed(Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info) {
5789  notify_table_changed(ha_alter_info);
5790  }
5791 
5792  protected:
5793  /**
5794  Allows the storage engine to update internal structures with concurrent
5795  writes blocked. If check_if_supported_inplace_alter() returns
5796  HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE or
5797  HA_ALTER_INPLACE_SHARED_AFTER_PREPARE, this function is called with
5798  exclusive lock otherwise the same level of locking as for
5799  inplace_alter_table() will be used.
5800 
5801  @note Should be no-op for instant algorithm.
5802 
5803  @note Storage engines are responsible for reporting any errors by
5804  calling my_error()/print_error()
5805 
5806  @note If this function reports error, commit_inplace_alter_table()
5807  will be called with commit= false.
5808 
5809  @note For partitioning, failing to prepare one partition, means that
5810  commit_inplace_alter_table() will be called to roll back changes for
5811  all partitions. This means that commit_inplace_alter_table() might be
5812  called without prepare_inplace_alter_table() having been called first
5813  for a given partition.
5814 
5815  @param altered_table TABLE object for new version of table.
5816  @param ha_alter_info Structure describing changes to be done
5817  by ALTER TABLE and holding data used
5818  during in-place alter.
5819  @param old_table_def dd::Table object describing old version of
5820  the table.
5821  @param new_table_def dd::Table object for the new version of the
5822  table. Can be adjusted by this call if SE
5823  supports atomic DDL. These changes to the
5824  table definition will be persisted in the
5825  data-dictionary at statement commit time.
5826 
5827  @retval true Error
5828  @retval false Success
5829  */
5830  virtual bool prepare_inplace_alter_table(
5831  TABLE *altered_table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5832  Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5833  const dd::Table *old_table_def MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5834  dd::Table *new_table_def MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5835  return false;
5836  }
5837 
5838  /**
5839  Alter the table structure in-place with operations specified using
5840  HA_ALTER_FLAGS and Alter_inplace_info. The level of concurrency allowed
5841  during this operation depends on the return value from
5842  check_if_supported_inplace_alter().
5843 
5844  @note Should be no-op for instant algorithm.
5845 
5846  @note Storage engines are responsible for reporting any errors by
5847  calling my_error()/print_error()
5848 
5849  @note If this function reports error, commit_inplace_alter_table()
5850  will be called with commit= false.
5851 
5852  @param altered_table TABLE object for new version of table.
5853  @param ha_alter_info Structure describing changes to be done
5854  by ALTER TABLE and holding data used
5855  during in-place alter.
5856  @param old_table_def dd::Table object describing old version of
5857  the table.
5858  @param new_table_def dd::Table object for the new version of the
5859  table. Can be adjusted by this call if SE
5860  supports atomic DDL. These changes to the
5861  table definition will be persisted in the
5862  data-dictionary at statement commit time.
5863 
5864  @retval true Error
5865  @retval false Success
5866  */
5867  virtual bool inplace_alter_table(
5868  TABLE *altered_table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5869  Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5870  const dd::Table *old_table_def MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5871  dd::Table *new_table_def MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5872  return false;
5873  }
5874 
5875  /**
5876  Commit or rollback the changes made during prepare_inplace_alter_table()
5877  and inplace_alter_table() inside the storage engine.
5878  Note that in case of rollback the allowed level of concurrency during
5879  this operation will be the same as for inplace_alter_table() and thus
5880  might be higher than during prepare_inplace_alter_table(). (For example,
5881  concurrent writes were blocked during prepare, but might not be during
5882  rollback).
5883 
5884  @note This is the place where SE changes happen for instant algorithm.
5885 
5886  @note For storage engines supporting atomic DDL this method should only
5887  prepare for the commit but do not finalize it. Real commit should happen
5888  later when the whole statement is committed. Also in some situations
5889  statement might be rolled back after call to commit_inplace_alter_table()
5890  for such storage engines. In the latter special case SE might require call
5891  to handlerton::dict_cache_reset() in order to invalidate its internal
5892  table definition cache after rollback.
5893 
5894  @note Storage engines are responsible for reporting any errors by
5895  calling my_error()/print_error()
5896 
5897  @note If this function with commit= true reports error, it will be called
5898  again with commit= false.
5899 
5900  @note In case of partitioning, this function might be called for rollback
5901  without prepare_inplace_alter_table() having been called first.
5902  Also partitioned tables sets ha_alter_info->group_commit_ctx to a NULL
5903  terminated array of the partitions handlers and if all of them are
5904  committed as one, then group_commit_ctx should be set to NULL to indicate
5905  to the partitioning handler that all partitions handlers are committed.
5906  @see prepare_inplace_alter_table().
5907 
5908  @param altered_table TABLE object for new version of table.
5909  @param ha_alter_info Structure describing changes to be done
5910  by ALTER TABLE and holding data used
5911  during in-place alter.
5912  @param commit True => Commit, False => Rollback.
5913  @param old_table_def dd::Table object describing old version of
5914  the table.
5915  @param new_table_def dd::Table object for the new version of the
5916  table. Can be adjusted by this call if SE
5917  supports atomic DDL. These changes to the
5918  table definition will be persisted in the
5919  data-dictionary at statement commit time.
5920 
5921  @retval true Error
5922  @retval false Success
5923  */
5924  virtual bool commit_inplace_alter_table(
5925  TABLE *altered_table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5926  Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5927  bool commit MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5928  const dd::Table *old_table_def MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
5929  dd::Table *new_table_def MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
5930  /* Nothing to commit/rollback, mark all handlers committed! */
5931  ha_alter_info->group_commit_ctx = nullptr;
5932  return false;
5933  }
5934 
5935  /**
5936  Notify the storage engine that the table definition has been updated.
5937 
5938  @param ha_alter_info Structure describing changes done by
5939  ALTER TABLE and holding data used
5940  during in-place alter.
5941 
5942  @note No errors are allowed during notify_table_changed().
5943 
5944  @note For storage engines supporting atomic DDL this method is invoked
5945  after the whole ALTER TABLE is completed and committed.
5946  Particularly this means that for ALTER TABLE statements with RENAME
5947  clause TABLE/handler object used for invoking this method will be
5948  associated with new table name. If storage engine needs to know
5949  the old schema and table name in this method for some reason it
5950  has to use ha_alter_info object to figure it out.
5951  */
5952  virtual void notify_table_changed(
5953  Alter_inplace_info *ha_alter_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {}
5954 
5955  public:
5956  /* End of On-line/in-place ALTER TABLE interface. */
5957 
5958  /**
5959  use_hidden_primary_key() is called in case of an update/delete when
5960  (table_flags() and HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_DELETE) is defined
5961  but we don't have a primary key
5962  */
5963  virtual void use_hidden_primary_key();
5964 
5965  protected:
5966  /* Service methods for use by storage engines. */
5967  void ha_statistic_increment(ulonglong System_status_var::*offset) const;
5968  THD *ha_thd(void) const;
5969 
5970  /**
5971  Acquire the instrumented table information from a table share.
5972  @param share a table share
5973  @return an instrumented table share, or NULL.
5974  */
5975  PSI_table_share *ha_table_share_psi(const TABLE_SHARE *share) const;
5976 
5977  /**
5978  Default rename_table() and delete_table() rename/delete files with a
5979  given name and extensions from handlerton::file_extensions.
5980 
5981  These methods can be overridden, but their default implementation
5982  provide useful functionality.
5983 
5984  @param [in] from Path for the old table name.
5985  @param [in] to Path for the new table name.
5986  @param [in] from_table_def Old version of definition for table
5987  being renamed (i.e. prior to rename).
5988  @param [in,out] to_table_def New version of definition for table
5989  being renamed. Storage engines which
5990  support atomic DDL (i.e. having
5991  HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL flag set)
5992  are allowed to adjust this object.
5993 
5994  @retval >0 Error.
5995  @retval 0 Success.
5996  */
5997  virtual int rename_table(const char *from, const char *to,
5998  const dd::Table *from_table_def,
5999  dd::Table *to_table_def);
6000 
6001  /**
6002  Delete a table.
6003 
6004  Used to delete a table. By the time delete_table() has been called all
6005  opened references to this table will have been closed (and your globally
6006  shared references released. The variable name will just be the name of
6007  the table. You will need to remove any files you have created at this
6008  point. Called for base as well as temporary tables.
6009 
6010  @param name Full path of table name.
6011  @param table_def dd::Table describing table being deleted
6012  (can be NULL for temporary tables created
6013  by optimizer).
6014 
6015  @return Zero on success, nonzero otherwise.
6016  */
6017  virtual int delete_table(const char *name, const dd::Table *table_def);
6018 
6019  private:
6020  /* Private helpers */
6021  void mark_trx_read_write();
6022  /*
6023  Low-level primitives for storage engines. These should be
6024  overridden by the storage engine class. To call these methods, use
6025  the corresponding 'ha_*' method above.
6026  */
6027 
6028  virtual int open(const char *name, int mode, uint test_if_locked,
6029  const dd::Table *table_def) = 0;
6030  virtual int close(void) = 0;
6031  virtual int index_init(uint idx, bool sorted MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6032  active_index = idx;
6033  return 0;
6034  }
6035  virtual int index_end() {
6036  active_index = MAX_KEY;
6037  return 0;
6038  }
6039  /**
6040  rnd_init() can be called two times without rnd_end() in between
6041  (it only makes sense if scan=1).
6042  then the second call should prepare for the new table scan (e.g
6043  if rnd_init allocates the cursor, second call should position it
6044  to the start of the table, no need to deallocate and allocate it again
6045  */
6046  virtual int rnd_init(bool scan) = 0;
6047  virtual int rnd_end() { return 0; }
6048  /**
6049  Write a row.
6050 
6051  write_row() inserts a row. buf is a byte array of data, normally
6052  record[0].
6053 
6054  You can use the field information to extract the data from the native byte
6055  array type.
6056 
6057  Example of this would be:
6058  for (Field **field=table->field ; *field ; field++)
6059  {
6060  ...
6061  }
6062 
6063  @param buf Buffer to write from.
6064 
6065  @return Operation status.
6066  @retval 0 Success.
6067  @retval != 0 Error code.
6068  */
6069  virtual int write_row(uchar *buf MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6070  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6071  }
6072 
6073  /**
6074  Update a single row.
6075 
6076  Note: If HA_ERR_FOUND_DUPP_KEY is returned, the handler must read
6077  all columns of the row so MySQL can create an error message. If
6078  the columns required for the error message are not read, the error
6079  message will contain garbage.
6080  */
6081  virtual int update_row(const uchar *old_data MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6082  uchar *new_data MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6083  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6084  }
6085 
6086  virtual int delete_row(const uchar *buf MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6087  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6088  }
6089  /**
6090  Reset state of file to after 'open'.
6091  This function is called after every statement for all tables used
6092  by that statement.
6093  */
6094  virtual int reset() { return 0; }
6095  virtual Table_flags table_flags(void) const = 0;
6096  /**
6097  Is not invoked for non-transactional temporary tables.
6098 
6099  Tells the storage engine that we intend to read or write data
6100  from the table. This call is prefixed with a call to handler::store_lock()
6101  and is invoked only for those handler instances that stored the lock.
6102 
6103  Calls to @c rnd_init / @c index_init are prefixed with this call. When table
6104  IO is complete, we call @code external_lock(F_UNLCK) @endcode.
6105  A storage engine writer should expect that each call to
6106  @code ::external_lock(F_[RD|WR]LOCK @endcode is followed by a call to
6107  @code ::external_lock(F_UNLCK) @endcode. If it is not, it is a bug in MySQL.
6108 
6109  The name and signature originate from the first implementation
6110  in MyISAM, which would call @c fcntl to set/clear an advisory
6111  lock on the data file in this method.
6112 
6113  Originally this method was used to set locks on file level to enable
6114  several MySQL Servers to work on the same data. For transactional
6115  engines it has been "abused" to also mean start and end of statements
6116  to enable proper rollback of statements and transactions. When LOCK
6117  TABLES has been issued the start_stmt method takes over the role of
6118  indicating start of statement but in this case there is no end of
6119  statement indicator(?).
6120 
6121  Called from lock.cc by lock_external() and unlock_external(). Also called
6122  from sql_table.cc by copy_data_between_tables().
6123 
6124  @param thd the current thread
6125  @param lock_type F_RDLCK, F_WRLCK, F_UNLCK
6126 
6127  @return non-0 in case of failure, 0 in case of success.
6128  When lock_type is F_UNLCK, the return value is ignored.
6129  */
6130  virtual int external_lock(THD *thd MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6131  int lock_type MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6132  return 0;
6133  }
6134  virtual void release_auto_increment() { return; }
6135  /** admin commands - called from mysql_admin_table */
6136  virtual int check_for_upgrade(HA_CHECK_OPT *) { return 0; }
6137  virtual int check(THD *, HA_CHECK_OPT *) { return HA_ADMIN_NOT_IMPLEMENTED; }
6138 
6139  /**
6140  In this method check_opt can be modified
6141  to specify CHECK option to use to call check()
6142  upon the table.
6143  */
6144  virtual int repair(THD *, HA_CHECK_OPT *) {
6145  DBUG_ASSERT(!(ha_table_flags() & HA_CAN_REPAIR));
6146  return HA_ADMIN_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
6147  }
6148  virtual void start_bulk_insert(ha_rows) {}
6149  virtual int end_bulk_insert() { return 0; }
6150 
6151  /**
6152  Does this handler want to get a Record_buffer for multi-row reads
6153  via the ha_set_record_buffer() function? And if so, what is the
6154  maximum number of records to allocate space for in the buffer?
6155 
6156  Storage engines that support using a Record_buffer should override
6157  this function and return true for scans that could benefit from a
6158  buffer.
6159 
6160  @param[out] max_rows gets set to the maximum number of records to
6161  allocate space for in the buffer if the function
6162  returns true
6163 
6164  @retval true if the handler would like a Record_buffer
6165  @retval false if the handler does not want a Record_buffer
6166  */
6167  virtual bool is_record_buffer_wanted(ha_rows *const max_rows) const {
6168  *max_rows = 0;
6169  return false;
6170  }
6171 
6172  // Set se_private_id and se_private_data during upgrade
6173  virtual bool upgrade_table(THD *thd MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6174  const char *dbname MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6175  const char *table_name MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6176  dd::Table *dd_table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6177  return false;
6178  }
6179 
6180  /** Initialize sampling.
6181  @param[out] scan_ctx A scan context created by this method that has to be
6182  used in sample_next
6183  @param[in] sampling_percentage percentage of records that need to be sampled
6184  @param[in] sampling_seed random seed
6185  @param[in] sampling_method sampling method to be used; currently only
6186  SYSTEM sampling is supported
6187  @return 0 for success, else failure. */
6188  virtual int sample_init(void *&scan_ctx, double sampling_percentage,
6189  int sampling_seed,
6190  enum_sampling_method sampling_method);
6191 
6192  /** Get the next record for sampling.
6193  @param[in] scan_ctx Scan context of the sampling
6194  @param[in] buf buffer to place the read record
6195  @return 0 for success, else failure. */
6196  virtual int sample_next(void *scan_ctx, uchar *buf);
6197 
6198  /** End sampling.
6199  @param[in] scan_ctx Scan context of the sampling
6200  @return 0 for success, else failure. */
6201  virtual int sample_end(void *scan_ctx);
6202 
6203  /**
6204  * Loads a table into its defined secondary storage engine.
6205  *
6206  * @param table Table opened in primary storage engine. Its read_set tells
6207  * which columns to load.
6208  *
6209  * @return 0 if success, error code otherwise.
6210  */
6211  virtual int load_table(const TABLE &table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6212  /* purecov: begin inspected */
6213  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
6214  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6215  /* purecov: end */
6216  }
6217 
6218  /**
6219  * Unloads a table from its defined secondary storage engine.
6220  *
6221  * @param db_name Database name.
6222  * @param table_name Table name.
6223  * @param error_if_not_loaded If true, then errors will be reported by this
6224  * function. If false, no errors will be reported
6225  * (silently fail). This case of false is useful
6226  * during DROP TABLE where a failure to unload
6227  * should not prevent dropping the whole table.
6228  * @return 0 if success, error code otherwise.
6229  */
6230  virtual int unload_table(const char *db_name MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6231  const char *table_name MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6232  bool error_if_not_loaded MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6233  /* purecov: begin inspected */
6234  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
6235  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6236  /* purecov: end */
6237  }
6238 
6239  protected:
6240  virtual int index_read(uchar *buf MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6241  const uchar *key MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6242  uint key_len MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6243  enum ha_rkey_function find_flag
6244  MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6245  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6246  }
6247  virtual int index_read_last(uchar *buf MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6248  const uchar *key MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6249  uint key_len MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6250  set_my_errno(HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND);
6251  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6252  }
6253 
6254  public:
6255  /**
6256  This method is similar to update_row, however the handler doesn't need
6257  to execute the updates at this point in time. The handler can be certain
6258  that another call to bulk_update_row will occur OR a call to
6259  exec_bulk_update before the set of updates in this query is concluded.
6260 
6261  Note: If HA_ERR_FOUND_DUPP_KEY is returned, the handler must read
6262  all columns of the row so MySQL can create an error message. If
6263  the columns required for the error message are not read, the error
6264  message will contain garbage.
6265 
6266  @param old_data Old record
6267  @param new_data New record
6268  @param dup_key_found Number of duplicate keys found
6269 
6270  */
6271  virtual int bulk_update_row(const uchar *old_data MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6272  uchar *new_data MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6273  uint *dup_key_found MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6274  DBUG_ASSERT(false);
6275  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6276  }
6277  /**
6278  Delete all rows in a table.
6279 
6280  This is called both for cases of truncate and for cases where the
6281  optimizer realizes that all rows will be removed as a result of an
6282  SQL statement.
6283 
6284  If the handler don't support this, then this function will
6285  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND and MySQL will delete the rows one
6286  by one.
6287  */
6288  virtual int delete_all_rows() {
6289  set_my_errno(HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND);
6290  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6291  }
6292  /**
6293  Quickly remove all rows from a table.
6294 
6295  @param[in,out] table_def dd::Table object for table being truncated.
6296 
6297  @remark This method is responsible for implementing MySQL's TRUNCATE
6298  TABLE statement, which is a DDL operation. As such, a engine
6299  can bypass certain integrity checks and in some cases avoid
6300  fine-grained locking (e.g. row locks) which would normally be
6301  required for a DELETE statement.
6302 
6303  @remark Typically, truncate is not used if it can result in integrity
6304  violation. For example, truncate is not used when a foreign
6305  key references the table, but it might be used if foreign key
6306  checks are disabled.
6307 
6308  @remark Engine is responsible for resetting the auto-increment counter.
6309 
6310  @remark The table is locked in exclusive mode. All open TABLE/handler
6311  instances except the one which is used for truncate() call
6312  are closed.
6313 
6314  @note It is assumed that transactional storage engines implementing
6315  this method can revert its effects if transaction is rolled
6316  back (e.g. because we failed to write statement to the binary
6317  log).
6318 
6319  @note Changes to dd::Table object done by this method will be saved
6320  to data-dictionary only if storage engine supports atomic DDL
6321  (i.e. has HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL flag set).
6322  */
6323  virtual int truncate(dd::Table *table_def MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6324  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6325  }
6326  virtual int optimize(THD *, HA_CHECK_OPT *) {
6327  return HA_ADMIN_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
6328  }
6329  virtual int analyze(THD *, HA_CHECK_OPT *) {
6330  return HA_ADMIN_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
6331  }
6332 
6333  /**
6334  @brief Check and repair the table if necessary.
6335 
6336  @param thd Thread object
6337 
6338  @retval true Error/Not supported
6339  @retval false Success
6340 
6341  @note Called if open_table_from_share fails and is_crashed().
6342  */
6343 
6344  virtual bool check_and_repair(THD *thd MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6345  return true;
6346  }
6347 
6348  /**
6349  Disable indexes for a while.
6350 
6351  @param mode Mode.
6352 
6353  @retval 0 Success.
6354  @retval != 0 Error.
6355  */
6356 
6357  virtual int disable_indexes(uint mode MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6358  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6359  }
6360 
6361  /**
6362  Enable indexes again.
6363 
6364  @param mode Mode.
6365 
6366  @retval 0 Success.
6367  @retval != 0 Error.
6368  */
6369 
6370  virtual int enable_indexes(uint mode MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6371  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6372  }
6373 
6374  /**
6375  Discard or import tablespace.
6376 
6377  @param [in] discard Indicates whether this is discard operation.
6378  @param [in,out] table_def dd::Table object describing the table
6379  in which tablespace needs to be discarded
6380  or imported. This object can be adjusted by
6381  storage engine if it supports atomic DDL
6382  (i.e. has HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL flag set).
6383  These changes will be persisted in the
6384  data-dictionary.
6385  @retval 0 Success.
6386  @retval != 0 Error.
6387  */
6388 
6389  virtual int discard_or_import_tablespace(bool discard MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6390  dd::Table *table_def
6391  MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6392  set_my_errno(HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND);
6393  return HA_ERR_WRONG_COMMAND;
6394  }
6395 
6396  virtual void drop_table(const char *name);
6397 
6398  /**
6399  Create table (implementation).
6400 
6401  @param [in] name Table name.
6402  @param [in] form TABLE object describing the table to be
6403  created.
6404  @param [in] info HA_CREATE_INFO describing table.
6405  @param [in,out] table_def dd::Table object describing the table
6406  to be created. This object can be
6407  adjusted by storage engine if it
6408  supports atomic DDL (i.e. has
6409  HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL flag set).
6410  These changes will be persisted in the
6411  data-dictionary. Can be NULL for
6412  temporary tables created by optimizer.
6413 
6414  @retval 0 Success.
6415  @retval non-0 Error.
6416  */
6417  virtual int create(const char *name, TABLE *form, HA_CREATE_INFO *info,
6418  dd::Table *table_def) = 0;
6419 
6420  virtual bool get_se_private_data(dd::Table *dd_table MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6421  bool reset MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6422  return false;
6423  }
6424 
6425  /**
6426  Adjust definition of table to be created by adding implicit columns
6427  and indexes necessary for the storage engine.
6428 
6429  @param [in] create_info HA_CREATE_INFO describing the table.
6430  @param [in] create_list List of columns in the table.
6431  @param [in] key_info Array of KEY objects describing table
6432  indexes.
6433  @param [in] key_count Number of indexes in the table.
6434  @param [in,out] table_obj dd::Table object describing the table
6435  to be created. Implicit columns and
6436  indexes are to be added to this object.
6437  Adjusted table description will be
6438  saved into the data-dictionary.
6439 
6440  @retval 0 Success.
6441  @retval non-0 Error.
6442  */
6443  virtual int get_extra_columns_and_keys(
6444  const HA_CREATE_INFO *create_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6445  const List<Create_field> *create_list MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6446  const KEY *key_info MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6447  uint key_count MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused)),
6448  dd::Table *table_obj MY_ATTRIBUTE((unused))) {
6449  return 0;
6450  }
6451 
6452  virtual bool set_ha_share_ref(Handler_share **arg_ha_share) {
6453  ha_share = arg_ha_share;
6454  return false;
6455  }
6456 
6457  void set_ha_table(TABLE *table_arg) { table = table_arg; }
6458 
6459  int get_lock_type() const { return m_lock_type; }
6460 
6461  /**
6462  Callback function that will be called by my_prepare_gcolumn_template
6463  once the table has been opened.
6464  */
6465  typedef void (*my_gcolumn_template_callback_t)(const TABLE *, void *);
6466  static bool my_prepare_gcolumn_template(THD *thd, const char *db_name,
6467  const char *table_name,
6468  my_gcolumn_template_callback_t myc,
6469  void *ib_table);
6470  static bool my_eval_gcolumn_expr_with_open(THD *thd, const char *db_name,
6471  const char *table_name,
6472  const MY_BITMAP *const fields,
6473  uchar *record,
6474  const char **mv_data_ptr,
6475  ulong *mv_length);
6476 
6477  /**
6478  Callback for computing generated column values.
6479 
6480  Storage engines that need to have virtual column values for a row
6481  can use this function to get the values computed. The storage
6482  engine must have filled in the values for the base columns that
6483  the virtual columns depend on.
6484 
6485  @param thd thread handle
6486  @param table table object
6487  @param fields bitmap of field index of evaluated generated
6488  column
6489  @param[in,out] record buff of base columns generated column depends.
6490  After calling this function, it will be
6491  used to return the value of the generated
6492  columns.
6493  @param[out] mv_data_ptr When given (not null) and the field
6494  needs to be calculated is a typed array field, it
6495  will contain pointer to field's calculated value.
6496  @param[out] mv_length Length of the data above
6497 
6498  @retval true in case of error
6499  @retval false on success
6500  */
6501  static bool my_eval_gcolumn_expr(THD *thd, TABLE *table,
6502  const MY_BITMAP *const fields, uchar *record,
6503  const char **mv_data_ptr, ulong *mv_length);
6504 
6505  /* This must be implemented if the handlerton's partition_flags() is set. */
6506  virtual Partition_handler *get_partition_handler() { return nullptr; }
6507 
6508  /**
6509  Set se_private_id and se_private_data during upgrade
6510 
6511  @param thd Pointer of THD
6512  @param dbname Database name
6513  @param table_name Table name
6514  @param dd_table dd::Table for the table
6515  @param table_arg TABLE object for the table.
6516 
6517  @return Operation status
6518  @retval false Success
6519  @retval true Error
6520  */
6521 
6522  bool ha_upgrade_table(THD *thd, const char *dbname, const char *table_name,
6523  dd::Table *dd_table, TABLE *table_arg);
6524 
6525  /**
6526  Store a pointer to the handler of the primary table that
6527  corresponds to the secondary table in this handler.
6528  */
6529  void ha_set_primary_handler(handler *primary_handler);
6530 
6531  /**
6532  Get a pointer to a handler for the table in the primary storage
6533  engine, if this handler is for a table in a secondary storage
6534  engine.
6535  */
6536  handler *ha_get_primary_handler() const { return m_primary_handler; }
6537 
6538  /**
6539  Return max limits for a single set of multi-valued keys
6540 
6541  @param[out] num_keys number of keys to store
6542  @param[out] keys_length total length of keys, bytes
6543  */
6544  void ha_mv_key_capacity(uint *num_keys, size_t *keys_length) const {
6545  return mv_key_capacity(num_keys, keys_length);
6546  }
6547 
6548  private:
6549  /**
6550  Engine-specific function for ha_can_store_mv_keys().
6551  Dummy function. SE's overloaded method is used instead.
6552  */
6553  /* purecov: begin inspected */
6554  virtual void mv_key_capacity(uint *num_keys, size_t *keys_length) const {
6555  *num_keys = 0;
6556  *keys_length = 0;
6557  }
6558  /* purecov: end */
6559 
6560  /**
6561  Filter duplicate records when multi-valued index is used for retrieval
6562 
6563  @returns
6564  true duplicate, such row id was already seen
6565  false row id is seen for the first time
6566  */
6567  bool filter_dup_records();
6568 
6569  protected:
6570  Handler_share *get_ha_share_ptr();
6571  void set_ha_share_ptr(Handler_share *arg_ha_share);
6572  void lock_shared_ha_data();
6573  void unlock_shared_ha_data();
6574 
6575  friend class DsMrr_impl;
6576 };
6577 
6578 /**
6579  Function identifies any old data type present in table.
6580 
6581  This function was handler::check_old_types().
6582  Function is not part of SE API. It is now converted to
6583  auxiliary standalone function.
6584 
6585  @param[in] table TABLE object
6586  @param[in] check_temporal_upgrade Check if temporal upgrade is needed
6587 
6588  @retval 0 ON SUCCESS
6589  @retval error code ON FAILURE
6590 */
6591 
6592 int check_table_for_old_types(const TABLE *table, bool check_temporal_upgrade);
6593 
6594 /*
6595  A Disk-Sweep MRR interface implementation
6596 
6597  This implementation makes range (and, in the future, 'ref') scans to read
6598  table rows in disk sweeps.
6599 
6600  Currently it is used by MyISAM and InnoDB. Potentially it can be used with
6601  any table handler that has non-clustered indexes and on-disk rows.
6602 */
6603 
6604 class DsMrr_impl {
6605  public:
6606  DsMrr_impl(handler *owner) : h(owner), table(nullptr), h2(nullptr) {}
6607 
6608  ~DsMrr_impl() {
6609  /*
6610  If ha_reset() has not been called then the h2 dialog might still
6611  exist. This must be closed and deleted (this is the case for
6612  internally created temporary tables).
6613  */
6614  if (h2) reset();
6615  DBUG_ASSERT(h2 == nullptr);
6616  }
6617 
6618  private:
6619  /*
6620  The "owner" handler object (the one that calls dsmrr_XXX functions.
6621  It is used to retrieve full table rows by calling rnd_pos().
6622  */
6623  handler *const h;
6624  TABLE *table; /* Always equal to h->table */
6625 
6626  /* Secondary handler object. It is used for scanning the index */
6627  handler *h2;
6628 
6629  /* Buffer to store rowids, or (rowid, range_id) pairs */
6630  uchar *rowids_buf;
6631  uchar *rowids_buf_cur; /* Current position when reading/writing */
6632  uchar *rowids_buf_last; /* When reading: end of used buffer space */
6633  uchar *rowids_buf_end; /* End of the buffer */
6634 
6635  bool dsmrr_eof; /* true <=> We have reached EOF when reading index tuples */
6636 
6637  /* true <=> need range association, buffer holds {rowid, range_id} pairs */
6638  bool is_mrr_assoc;
6639 
6640  bool use_default_impl; /* true <=> shortcut all calls to default MRR impl */
6641  public:
6642  /**
6643  Initialize the DsMrr_impl object.
6644 
6645  This object is used for both doing default MRR scans and DS-MRR scans.
6646  This function just initializes the object. To do a DS-MRR scan,
6647  this must also be initialized by calling dsmrr_init().
6648 
6649  @param table_arg pointer to the TABLE that owns the handler
6650  */
6651 
6652  void init(TABLE *table_arg) {
6653  DBUG_ASSERT(table_arg != nullptr);
6654  table = table_arg;
6655  }
6656 
6657  int dsmrr_init(RANGE_SEQ_IF *seq_funcs, void *seq_init_param, uint n_ranges,
6658  uint mode, HANDLER_BUFFER *buf);
6659  void dsmrr_close();
6660 
6661  /**
6662  Resets the DS-MRR object to the state it had after being intialized.
6663
